pros:
If you enjoy sitting at your desk killing time for months at a time, then this is the
place for you.  On several occasions, I asked co-workers "has anyone told you
what we're suppose to be doing ?".  The response was "No."  Then, when
something finally came down the line ...   Read "Cons"
cons:
Very politically charged situation that has nothing to do with ability or accomplishments.  
If you brown nose then, even though you can't figure out why your C++ code won't compile
on a Ada compiler, you can become a technical lead two years out of college.  And if you
do try to actually excel, you had better do it in less than 50 lines of code or your thick fix
will set off an alarm and you'll be sent packing because you might jepordize the "truck
load of money backing up to there door."  And since Arizona is a "right to work" state,
they can liable you and there is nothing that you can do about it.  Where is 60 minutes 
when you need them.

review_title: Good work/life balance, highly ethical
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II (E04) in Tucson, AZ
pros: One of the pro's to working at Raytheon is the very friendly and highly ethical environment you get to work in. They place a sincere emphasis on ethics year round as well as excellent annual training. Every single manager I've had has displayed a genuine interest in helping their people advance and improve themselves.
cons: There is too much emphasis on leadership roles to the extent that it's nearly impossible to advance without taking such a role on. The sad fact is that not everyone is really cut out for such a role. This has the unfortunate effect of driving some otherwise excellent individual contributors to seek out roles they neither enjoy nor perform well in; and in other cases failing to recognize the excellent contributions of those who prefer to stay as individual contributors.

review_title: Long time workers under appreciated
job_title: Senior Principal Systems Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: I like doing front end concept design work.  Uses a lot of my physics and work background.  Allows me to be creative and inventive.
cons: I am under appreciated for the type of work I do.  I seem to have hit a ceiling that I will never cross.  It is obvious that younger engineers are being hired in at my same title / pay grade, and are being paid more than I am.  It is also obvious that younger engineers are being given opportunities for advancement in their careers which are not offered to someone my age.  I do not enjoy my job anywhere near as much as I did 10 or 15 years ago, because of he lack of appreciation.

review_title: Overall Good Company
pros: Great benefits package with lots of perks. Interesting programs to work on. Respected brand name recognition. Can rub shoulders with brilliant minds.
cons: Be careful about which Raytheon location you work at. The culture is different at each site. The Albuquerque, NM site, for example, is not really very Raytheon-like in its culture. It's still Ktech in its mentality (it was acquired by Raytheon in 2011). And Ktech tends to fly by the seat of its pants. The various Ktech departments there are managed very differently -- they are almost companies within company.  Also, and this applies globally throughout Raytheon as a whole, the 9/80 work schedule sounds better than it really is. So take it with grain of when a recruiter or HR person tries to sell it to you.

review_title: Good place to get started, but make sure you start out doing what interests you.
job_title: Electrical Engineer II in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Raytheon is a decent place to get started.  They have enough projects going on that you will get put on something fairly quickly.  You can use your time here to get acquainted with engineering practices and enterprise processes that will be useful later on.

There are also some pretty interesting projects to work on.
cons:
As an electrical engineer looking to work on digital circuits, Raytheon IIS might not be the best place to work.  While a few projects make use of digital design skills, the majority are systems integration, which, while the concepts are interesting, connecting up COTS equipment is not the most interesting work.  I also find the bureaucracy makes altering course (even if the course is not ideal) to be difficult.

Also, some of management's responses to feedback can be annoying and less than helpful (the employee opinion survey said employees don't feel like we get enough respect...so now we get weekly Respectograms.  Thanks, that helps).

review_title: Pros and cons from a Finance organization perspective.
pros:
- Good benefits
- Some jobs have good work life balance (although people are getting more stretched year over year)
- Cross functional teams are enjoyable to work in
- Job stability
cons:
- Management is out of touch and micromanages throughout the businesses and within the functional matrix
- Difficult to find meaningful and challenging finance positions (a lot of positions are centered around report generation and consolidation of data)
- Sandbagging is encouraged over accuracy
- Have often heard the phrase "people are lucky to have a job" - this has led to a lot of high potentials leaving the company for better positions because they were unable to progress without "putting in their time"

review_title: Fun technical problems and good people, but management can be corrupt and clique-ish.
job_title: Senior Principal Systems Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Good pay, work can be fun.
Tucson is a good place to live with a low cost of living, nice climate, good university.
cons:
Management gets rewarded bonuses based on milestones reached.  I came up with a paper showing that missile performance would be poor in certain areas.  Their response was not to fix the problems, but rather throw me off the project, give me a poor performance review, then throw me out of the company (over a matter of months to build a paper trail).  

It's a good place to start a career, but it's very difficult to get any advancement unless you're part of the "in" crowd. 

They hire fewer people than they really need, so there can be compulsory overtime when things are busy.  When things are slow, they quickly lay off a lot of people.

review_title: Government leeches are on the way out.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Aurora, CO
pros: Most managers allow flexible schedules.
cons:
Raytheon is in a constant race to the bottom with Lockheed Martin. If Lock Mart only restocks their bathrooms once a week then Tuesday becomes "bring your own toilet paper to work day" at Raytheon too. Lock Mart doesn't have profit sharing so Raytheon has to stop that too (how can they be competitive if you don't cut standards?). Your career will become an effort to not stand out. If you bring up deficiencies in the processes that produce sub-standard code you will be singled out for poor performance reviews and slated for retaliation.
Record profits are don't mean raises that keep up with inflation. Raises have more to do with the party that holds the Presidency than what is actually happening in the world. Management sends out awkward emails that are legally allowed to "inform" voters which party is more likely to keep you from losing your job.

review_title: Raytheon IIS is a terrific place to work; you won't get rich doing so.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Falls Church, VA
pros: Flexible work schedule gives Raytheon employees a great work / life balance.  Pension and 401(K) match makes Raytheon's compensation package mostly unique, where employees get to "double dip."  Finally, with management approval, employees are offered opportunities to work beyond 40 hours per week and get compensation pay for the extended work week (at the equivalent salary $/hour).
cons: Slow moving (sometimes a glacial pace) company who reacts far to slowly to market and customer needs / wants.  The employees are inundated with process, which is constantly getting more restrictive, disallowing the employee to use their best judgment as to what makes sense.  The salary compensation is, I suspect, below average, but the overall compensation package is likely above average.  However, the upsides FAR outweigh the downsides.

review_title: Raytheon is a long term career type company.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Raytheon provides an even environment under which to develop a strong career in the defense industry.  By this, I mean the hours are very regular and the work is constructive in building technical abilities and long standing skills.  Projects are often rewarding with a strong mix of technical fields.  There are many opportunities to work with various technical disciplines to give you a very strong overall picture of the final products in development.
cons: Because of the natural pace of the defense industry, Raytheon has a significant amount of politics and bueracracy at the higher levels.  As with all companies, it must be dealt with and managed appropriately.  However, due to the higher levels of employee retention, old politics tend to play a larger role than in other companies.

review_title: Lousy management
job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros: Good pay and benefits. Three day weekends every other week.
cons:
Management has no desire to actually manage employees. Their goal is to hand off a task with zero preparatory work to make the employee successful. The employee is expected to dig up the information to do their job.They expect new employees to have years of experience in the defense industry and provide little to no training. Also a mindset of everything is classified making it difficult to obtain basic information to do your job.
Management then complains when employees are ineffective on the job. Many facilities are a revolving door with new hires leaving in disgust after 3 - 4 years working there. Very little opportunity for advancement, section heads are selected from those the dept manager has a long term friendship with. It is rare for an employee to be selected to be a section head due to department managers surrounding themselves with fellow employees they have worked with on projects for many years. This environment fosters a cut throat relationship with all the other employees. Don't be surprised if your fellow employees stab you in the back in order to gain favor with management.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
pros: Best part?  You get to support the U.S. & our Allies' world leadership, and all the heroes that make it possible.  WIIFM: There are lots of tools to advance your career (leadership opportunities and rotational programs, formal mentoring system, tuition reimbursement).  There are lots of travel opportunities to work and network around the country, and international assignments are available.  The culture is very open and inclusive.  Most everyone you will work with wants you to have opportunities to succeed.
cons: Work-life balance is medium at best.  There can be long hours.  There is a 9-80 schedule available, but you don't always get to use it, due to workload.  Also, either plan for using an HSA with a high-deductible plan, or spending big money on your health insurance premium.  As a defense contractor, things can move pretty slow.  There is some resistance to change (some of it from the union).  Also, the typical manufacturing industry challenges, like layoffs, unions, outsourcing work.

review_title: Program Manager
pros: The compensation was good.  That was all.
cons: I was offered a competitive salary and a generous signing bonus in order to relocate from Northern California.  The signing bonus was to offset the relocation repayment to my previous employer for having only worked there less than a year.  I could have started two months later and not have had to repay it.  However, Raytheon was pushing me to start sooner than later.  They even waived the requirement for a secret security clearance as mine had lapsed and put me in for an interim so that I could perform my job.  All that sounds great, but then they laid me off 5 months later due to alleged funding issues.

review_title: Good, but not great
pros:
* Great life/work balance
* Flexible hours (many managers are sensitive to commutes/child care issues)
* Interesting work
* Fair compensation
* Relatively low stress
* 9/80 work week (businesses) or summer hours (corporate)
* Resources (on-site dry cleaning/banking/health services/cafeteria)
* Many nice people
cons:
* Can be cliquey - much like high school
* Some paranoid people - lack of trust for no reason
* Senior management is not approachable/visible
* Some people are stuck in their ways
* Change is difficult - often have to do things the "Raytheon way", just because
* Poor communication between managers and employees
* Lack of transparency
* No formal telecommuting policy 
* Hypocrisy - huge emphasis is placed on respect, yet many people don't even acknowledge co-workers in the hall
* Many levels makes it difficult to complete projects
* Difficult to get promoted/move into new roles. You are losing talented people.

review_title: Bad management makes it hard for Generation Y.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexible work hours. Good benefits, pay, and 401k contribution.
cons: Lack of innovation and creativity. The work environment is very plain. Culture in the company is all about collecting a paycheck. The company acts like they care about trust, respect, and diversity but these don't seem to be enforced where it matters. Managers aren't evaluated from upper management or employees.

review_title: Overall a good company. Does great things for National Security and the Warfighter.  Might have grown large too quickly.
pros: Lots of opportunity if you are willing and able to relocated nationally or even internationally.  Good tuition reimbursement programs.  Find a good respected mentor and you'll go far.
cons: From day one I sensed an issue with their internal communications, their On-Boarding process was embarrassing and that was a theme my entire time there.  They will stress Values and Accountability, but may not execute them as advertised 100% of them time... that was the hardest thing to accept. That and the culture presence itself as very

review_title: All-in hiring, non-existent retention efforts
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Fullerton, CA
pros: There are good mentors floating around, and if you can find one, it makes working here invaluable.  I have gained a lot of competitive work experience thanks to amazing engineers who believed in me and took the time to mentor me.   I have several coworkers who feel the same way.  (Unfortunately a lot of those good mentors have left the company in the past couple of years.)
cons:
The company is putting extreme effort into hiring, while retention gets blown off. 
 Talented engineers who have been at the company for years watch new hires with less experience get hired in at significantly higher salaries and pay grades.  A significant portion of our top talent has left for more competitive commercial opportunities, and it just makes the workload more painful for the experienced employees who stay.

There is also some really painful discrimination going on at this company: be very cautious if you are a female.  Our HR department is absolutely incompetent.

review_title: Somewhere to start a career, but not to stay...
job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
-Stable paycheck
-Nice people for the most part
-Some interesting domestic and international work
cons:
-New people get good pay for the first year or two, but the salary doesn't increase much after that. You need to become a contractor or jump companies to get market value.
-Outdated systems and tools, you will probably not add many useful skills to your resume.
-Lots of overtime and weekend work. Work life balance is not usually great.
-Not many new projects right now, which means that sites are still letting people go while replacing them with less expensive alternatives.

review_title: Fun and Challenging Experience
job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Though thing started off pretty slow after a few months I was pull into a variety of challenging projects for my program. The leads have been great to work with and make a point of helping employees find roles which match their skill set and career aspirations. There are endless opportunities for people to step up and take on work which is both fun and challenging as well as having a good support system to help you get familiar with the technology and processes.
cons: Like most large companies they struggle with the lag of executing decisions as well as different leaders making decision which can conflict with on another. There is a big opportunity for the company to improve the onboarding process so that new employees can get plugged into their team and roles more efficiently.

review_title: Lots of opportunity;  lots of red tape (review pertains to RTN before the merger)
pros: Enormous pride in working on technology to make the world a safer place, albeit unease at the application of some products in the Middle East. 9/30 Fridays a big plus with a pretty good benefits package. If you are interested in testing your abilities and want to learn new skills, there are plenty of opportunities here. From a technology perspective, few companies can claim to be more advanced. If you want to work on the latest in cyber, AI, hypersonics etc., this is the place for you.
cons: The proverbial turtle moves faster than the management team. The company is so big, and stuck in 'this is how we do it here', that agility is near impossible unless senior management makes it happen (and funds it). Margins are thin and senior management optimizes for stock performance. The end result: investment in emerging tech and employee-facing programs is a joke. Your experience will really be dictated by your manager and the program you work on. Be sure to evaluate those while considering a job at RTN.

review_title: Flexible, innovative place to work.
pros: Flexible work week.  We work a 9/80 schedule which means we get every other Friday off.  You get the opportunity to work with different technologies.  My job is constantly changing.
cons: Not very many.  The only Cons I've seen here are specific with people, not organizational.  In the past we had a hard time getting to do what you wanted to do.  But they've really opened that up.  Now if you'd like to work on FPGA's for example, you ask to be transferred to that department.  And if there's an opening, they'll likely move you over.

review_title: Raytheon Electrical Engineer 2 Review
job_title: Electrical Engineer II in Andover, MA
pros: "I have worked for Raytheon over 15 Years. Originally designated to oversee the flying prober development, working on small quantity that were than moved to bed of nail testers. Later requisitioned to work on both flying prober and bed of nail tester development, produced well over 2 hundred programs and fixtures over the course the years. Responsible for Shop monthly reports identifying FPY and recurring issues as well as solutions to resolve these problems. Worked with MFG engineers to ensure the procurement of correct components, also created excel data files to help technicians access the location of over 500 Spectrum fixtures with both in the shop and in third party storage. Continuously assisted Technicians improve their troubleshooting skill through on the job training aids. Involved in DFT programs with various design engineers, and completed training for Six Sigma improvements on a yearly basis, also completed classes in ESD, Safety and other OSHA requirements
cons: I have not had any problems working for Raytheon. Excellent Company, great benefits.

review_title: Sr. Systems Engineer
pros: Very effective health plan (pre ACA standardization). Decent to Very Effective health coverage (Post ACA). A lot of opportunities to submit, and be rewarded for, Intellectual Property creation/process improvement via development solutions that can result in a direct patent and/or hefty monetary award. Internal incentive program for doing "awards" for peers within company (not isolated to program/business sector) without being said awardee's supervisor/manager. Plant time off holiday hours  in addition to regular vacation/general leave/general holiday hours. A lot of employee benefits with major manufacturers and automotive industry
cons: Often times hard to transition from one program to another while in "field services support". Also, many perks that come with company may not trickle down to field engineering members depending on direct client needs (eg. Plant Holidays). Incentive to provide training through non-Raytheon provisioned training sources that are NOT colleges (eg: certification course centers), are hard to come by without coming out of pocket directly. Often beholden to legacy systems on certain programs due in large part to customer inability to purchase newer solutions (eg sequestration).

review_title: Tucson Mechanical Engineer
job_title: Mechanical Design Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: There are a lot of missile programs to move between so the job never gets boring. The people are great and the schedule is nice (9/80), and my favorite part are the technical resources.
cons: Leadership is very poor. I can't tell you how many times I was told, "Plan for success!" when I estimated time on my projects for trouble shooting, and design updates after key testing milestone. They basically want to design something, build one, test it, then submit to production without changing the design. Not all missile programs are like that at Raytheon, but enough of them are that it becomes a problem. Leadership needs improvement.

review_title: Good
pros: Great opportunity to learn. It's a challenging environment that tests you every day and prepares you for your next career move. The company works on exciting programs. The salaries are very good. Felt proud to work there.
cons: It's a tough culture, very cut-throat. Toxic. Competitive. There are a lot of good, smart people there. After a while, I couldn't take it anymore. I enjoyed the work but decided I needed to work in a less rigid, less bureaucratic, less toxic culture that would allow me to enjoy my life more rather than being constantly worried about my status at work. I would think twice before going there. Too many mind games.

review_title: Great products that support the warfighter but ethics and respect need to apply to employees at all levels
pros: Supports the warfighter.  Shuts down for a week at Christmas.
cons: Bogged down with over the top processes.  Far too much time spent on respect and ethics training which is often times ignored by "leaders".  Says they don't have "quotas" but based on the makeup of your particular location you are given a list each year stating you need to hire X number of women, X number of POC's (persons of color), etc.   Whether you are qualified or not seems to be secondary.

review_title: If you don't expect recognition or respect, you're in the right place.
pros: Pays decently well for the area, There's a lot of dead wood in the organization which makes it easy to be a "good" employee.  Most senior management is located somewhere else, so if you do good work you'll be left alone.  Global mentor program and training opportunities are exceptional if you know how to get hooked up.
cons:
Indianapolis is not head of a business unit, near a customer, or near the competition.  If you're 28-40 years old there's always going to be someone who's done an OK job for 25 years ahead of you -even if you're considered a rising star.  Indianapolis also gets fewer Holidays, less severance, and no Profit Share when compared to most other Raytheon sites.

Being far from senior management also means that getting noticed is difficult.  The line I hear most is "Aren't you happy you have a job?".  The "One Raytheon" philosophy isn't true.

review_title: Disappointed in the Management
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Aurora, CO
pros: Excellent benefits, excellent people, and good corporate resources provide a sense that the overall organization takes care of its people at a time when defense budgets are getting smaller.
cons:
Internal systems just don't measure up. Management does not act on employee inputs to improve internal business systems, yet can't produce a configuration managed baseline.

Organization uses Critical Chain to program detriment. Every IMS task is on critical chain, or so it would seem. CC takes away valuable resources from internal efforts. 

The internal performance evaluation process is truly the worst. Interim and year end reviews border on navel gaze. Program schedule prevent any effective employee development.

The internal management palpable dislike for each other results in constant churn in personnel from program to program. Expect zero continuity and a reorganization every six months. 

IIS has lost several large programs that have negatively impacted career growth division wide and resulted in the movement of people from program to program in Colorado.

review_title: Good, but plenty of drawbacks.  A good place to jump through on your way to a better place.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Falls Church, VA
pros: Good start salary.  Good benefits.  Lots of vacation.  Allowed to work 9/80 schedule.  Easy to get time off, even at the last minute.  Fantastic people to work with.  They're very laid back, but hard working.
cons: Very low raises.  They bring you in promising one job and giving you another.  Accept too much work than they're unable to staff, leading to everyone working lots of overtime.  Very cheap, especially when it comes to travel.  Managers are so overworked they don't have much time for reviews/give feedback.  In fact, employees usually write their own year-end review, which management can modify.

review_title: Don't get your hopes up
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Co-workers are intelligent and engaging. Many talented and smart people here.
cons:
Employees - most talented employees are underutilized or just overworked, and greatly unappreciated.  You can get pigeon holed quickly by many managers. 

Level 5 management -  a joke.  Same people, different management roles year after year, its like a giant pool of nepotistic dna with line level management.   

Upper management - out of touch with reality.  Couldn't be further removed from it than they are, almost like they have no original ideas and can only turn and run in the same direction other companies do - trend based management.

review_title: Great place, especially for senior level engineers.
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Lots of work to do and the company encourages mobility inside the company. Job security is high due to the constant disruptions happening around the world. Great people to work with and for. 9/80 work schedule with flex time available (i.e. 4/10s can be arranged). Find your niche and carve your own career here.

Pay is great compared to private sector jobs.
cons:
Large company with government contracts and oversight brings with it much bureaucracy. It can take months to get small tasks done due to the number of people that must be involved. For example, I cannot order a $2 screw online. I must submit it to an ordering department and sometimes wait a few months to receive what I could have bought on my own in a day or two.

Consistent but small raises. Not too bad if you come in at a high rate, but terrible for lower level employees.

review_title: SW Developer| Engineer
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Work with very intelligent, wonderful people on a project with a worldwide user base
Able to focus on Python scripting and application development
Very good benefits
cons:
Management was locked in a development mindset from the 1980s
The business was too big and too slow for its own good.
The development team was never able to acquire the right tools to do the job well. The entire development, testing and deployment process was bloated beyond usefulness, locked into a contract that crippled good judgment and efficiency.
So. Much. Rework. There was never time to do it right the first time, but there always seemed to be time to do it again.

review_title: Good place to have a long and stable career.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Van Nuys, CA
pros: Stability - one review I read said "once you are in, you're in."  Good benefits package.  Focus on work life balance with flex time, telecommute, etc.  Caring management and strong sense of community.  Plenty of support and time for learning.  Good educational assistance program.  Many lifers here as it is an easy place to put in a 30-40 year career.
cons: Not the most challenging place to work.  Plenty of bureaucracy.  Similar to working in a federal government organization.  Still a sense of hierarchy and "putting in your service" in order to advance.  Main business is weaponry - if that doesn't sit well with you it probably isn't a good fit.  Lots of ex-military employees.  Stability and predictability is paramount - ingenuity, innovation and risk taking are embraced in words but not in practice.

review_title: Up and Down
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: When there is work it is fun, but lately there hasn't been much (con).  Flexible schedule is great.  Location is great.  Dress is very casual.  Limited opportunity for tuition reimbursement.
cons: I transferred from Raytheon Missile Systems and absolutely enjoeyed Raytheon until I came to El Segundo (Space and Airborne Systems).  Work is slow and unstable and people are quick to stab you in the back.  Learning opportunities are limited unless you are willing to work for free.  Processes have flooded this place so getting work done is nearly impossible.  Work is not tailored to skillsets.  Some managers are awefull and tend to be those responsible for career development.  NO INOVATION CULTURE.  This company was founded on innovation and management has driven it out of the company.  Young talent is quickly leaving the company after only a few years.

review_title: Up and Down
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: When there is work it is fun, but lately there hasn't been much (con).  Flexible schedule is great.  Location is great.  Dress is very casual.  Limited opportunity for tuition reimbursement.
cons: I transferred from Raytheon Missile Systems and absolutely enjoeyed Raytheon until I came to El Segundo (Space and Airborne Systems).  Work is slow and unstable and people are quick to stab you in the back.  Learning opportunities are limited unless you are willing to work for free.  Processes have flooded this place so getting work done is nearly impossible.  Work is not tailored to skillsets.  Some managers are awefull and tend to be those responsible for career development.  NO INOVATION CULTURE.  This company was founded on innovation and management has driven it out of the company.  Young talent is quickly leaving the company after only a few years.

review_title: Great company and great people
pros: Raytheon employment has been a very good to me. Management is supportive of employee's career growth and provides opportunities in a fair manner across the company.  Benefits and compensation are at the top of the industry.  Employees take much pride in the very successful product line.  The work culture at Raytheon is team oriented and employees know that the key to their individual success is dependent on the success of the team and the company. This attitude fosters people helping others to succeed and the professional growth of all is enhanced.
cons: Within the Integrated Defense Systems (IDS) portion of the company, decision making power resides in Woburn, MA. Moving some of this management to Huntsville, AL and closer to the MDA customer would be a big benefit to both the company and the customer.  Because of this reluctance opportunities in Huntsville for career growth are limited.

review_title: Good work life balance, though not challenging
job_title: Electrical Engineer II in Sudbury, MA
pros:
Raytheon gives a very good work-life balance. The flex time is a bonus that is essential for people with children. The benefits are very good -- medical, dental, visual, other insurance benefits are comprehensive. On most projects, work is not too demanding, and could easily do 40 hours a week. This is significantly less than the more competitive commercial field. 
Education assistances towards obtaining higher degrees is readily available
Raytheon stresses on work ethics, most people treat each other with respect.
cons:
Compensation is competitive when you first enter, however, raises drop off to single digits. After about 3-5 years in the compny, it is not worth staying since your peers in the engineering field in outside industry is already making more. 
Work is not challenging, there is not much to learn. There is stress on processes, tend to do more process and paper work than actual design and engineering. May not be a good place to learn and grow as someone straight out of college.

review_title: Got promoted to a manager job nobody wanted and had to quit
pros:
The benefits, salary, vacation, security clearance. 
The relocation package offered to employees to get them to the door, I think 35k was a pretty decent amount.
cons:
Constantly being bullied, not cool. I wish work was easier but it was pretty dull. Constant curve balls, and change of direction that if you didn't duck or ran with the current you can get swallowed real easy. 

The team I managed was mediocre at best. Engineers were young and didn't have the smarts.

Everyone's attitude is to do whatever benefits themselves. The company and products come third, fourth, or fifth. Recruiting was hard, almost impossible to hire people to come to Forest given the low wages, vacation, and benefits offered. 

Hard to climb the ladder in a manufacturing facility. There is very little design work, therefore if you want to work on projects where you do the same things over and over this might be the place. If you want a dynamic place with different projects etc. look elsewhere.

review_title: Good company with competitive salary
job_title: Software Engineer I in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: In general Raytheon is a good company with good benefits.  SW teams typically consist of very down to earth, intelligent, hard working individuals.  Most of the leads and management are stern but understanding and easy to get a long with. The company has a strong work/life balance ethic and promotes healthy lifestyles and flexible work hours.  There are also many different work opportunities available to employees so its not uncommon for employees to bounce around to different business groups and job titles if they choose.
cons: As with most DODs in this time and age, the money is not stable.  Often times, programs and projects will stop on short notice due to funding cuts.   Layoffs and staffing reductions are a constant threat.  Many employees find themselves being forced to bounce around to new tasks and projects on a month by month or even week by week basis because funding issues.  Also be prepared for lots of process and documentation. SW engineers will spend as much time with process and documentation as they will coding (if not more time).

review_title: AVOID AT ALL COST
pros:
Nice Facilities
Free Popcorn
None after those 2
cons:
Everything lol
Work/Life balance 
Career Growth
Engaging work

review_title: Raytheon was a good company to work for
pros: They are truly a large corporation with all of the characteristics that go along with that.  Good processes in place, opportunities for advancement. The best part of Raytheon are the great people who work there.  Good compensation, but raise percentages were declining in the last 6 years; mirroring the employment environment; also driven by the particular area and focus of the business area you're in.
cons: Raytheon touts their people as their best and most important asset, but that doesn't match their decisions and actions.  Still a strongly dominated male environment in spite of some new female leaders appointed.  More challenging for women to be recognized as innovative contributors.  Very political company which drives leadership behavior, benefiting the leaderships' careers.  Indianapolis has different benefits than the other RTN companies.  Recommendation -- is if you have a choice, work for another division; but still a company I would work for again.

review_title: Managers Create a Culture of Do Nothing
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Torrance, CA
pros: Benefits are decent.  After 15 years of service, the company grants you 5 weeks of Paid Time Off.  You can't get that anywhere.
cons: Bad managers are hard to rid.  Face it.  Working for someone that you don't trust just doesn't work.  A manager that is a bully is even worse.  Even if 20 people have the same issue with the same person, it is hard to create a case to make a difference.  HR has built of culture of do nothing.  Employees that have approached HR to open a case create a lot of overhead and at the end, no change has occurred, no improvement in place and just a lot of awkwardness for the future.  Employees have been taught that it's better to "do nothing" thereby creating a cycle of doom and gloom.

review_title: Hard work, poor training, and poor collaboration...
pros: The pay is good at first glance and PTO is fair.
cons: The training here is awful especially considering your team can be spread out throughout the United States. The benefits are HSA only and can be expensive if you have children. Team collaboration is lacking because everyone is so bogged down with work. I am a new employee and have been giving 2 desk. I am sinking fast as I don't know what I am doing. The pay is good but after working 60 hours a week, my family life and weekends have suffered. You will never catch up on work and be working a lot. There is a reason they give you a laptop. The management is also clueless on how their employees are doing. You are on a sinking island and will drown quickly. Company morale here is low and turnover is high.

review_title: Large Defense Contractor But More Agile Than Others This Size
pros: Raytheon really focuses on retaining talent and utilizing on the job training. Advancement opportunities are good but sometimes lateral moves are the only way to advance. I've enjoyed my time at Raytheon, but the 2-3% raises, standard in this industry, won't retain talent.
cons:
2-4% raises every year
Lots of oversight but standard for defense industry
Upward mobility for a few chosen but if you're not chosen, do your two-three years and leave 
You'll know if you're a "chosen" one or not

review_title: Good overall experience.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Garland, TX
pros: Benefits: Not sure what they are for new hires these days, and I know they used to be even better a couple years before I signed up, but the benefits are good. 401k matching, health, life insurance. ~3% raises/year (I guess more if you get promoted). Performance sharing once a year, which depends on the business but it's generally a good amount. Good people and good team-focused environment (help each other out, etc). Another good benefit is flex time: you work 40 hrs/week, but on a given 2-week pay period you can flex time to/from a week, so as long as your manager is okay with it, you could work 35hrs one week and 45 the next (in a given pay period).
cons: My experience has mostly been positive. Sometimes the atmosphere can be negative around layoff time (which probably happens at other companies, too). Maybe it's just been my experience, but I seldom feel like complaining about my work day. So far I've been a part of good teams doing interesting/good work.

review_title: Sr Systems Engineer II
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: This is a large national company working there has decent benefits.  At Raytheon there are lots of interesting projects in the area of aerospace can be quite interesting and you access to some cutting edge technology.
cons: Some project has life cycles in the decades, which means it is possible for some to be pigeon holed as an important resource for a project that is essential on life support.  To avoid this you have to market yourself internally

review_title: Struggling to keep up
pros:
- Decent pay in a low-cost city.
- Smart people in many roles.
- Defense industry isn't wanting for money.
- Overtime past 40 hours can be paid at 1x for exempt roles (if your program and supervisor aren't stingy, but many are).
- Paid week off between Christmas and New Years.
cons:
- Way too much process where you don't want it, far too little where you do.
- Tech infrastructure is lagging years behind modern tech industry, and the company hasn't fully embraced the fact that it needs to be keeping up in order to thrive.
- Work hard and your annual raise still barely keeps up with inflation.
- Work/life balance can be terrible, depending on your program.
- Customer-is-always-right mentality from management, even when the customer makes unreasonable demands of the engineers.
- No separate sick leave, so everyone comes in sick to not burn PTO.
- Underperforming co-workers tend to stick around.
- Very employer-friendly timekeeping.
- Not seeing any of that corporate tax cut that the CEO keeps bragging to us about.

review_title: Ok stepping stone job, low raises and mediocre leadership
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros:
9/80
Great stepping stone if you plan to work at another defense company after your clearance comes in
cons:
Healthcare plan is a joke
Raises barely above inflation
Boring company culture
Middle management doesn't have a clue
Office politics preventing real work from being done
PM program so backlogged that you'll wait years before slots open
Doesn't recognize industry certs like 6S or PMP. Need to get recertified using their own proprietary system
High engineering turnover because of low pay and old Hughes employees holding on to middle-senior positions until they can cash out their pension

review_title: Stable but boring due to long lead product cycles.
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Denver, CO
pros: Stable, family-oriented, 9/80 work week (if you can negotiate this).  The programs last for years instead of months like at a commercial company, so people get lost in the long product cycle.
cons: Lack of creativity, lowered ambition due to long government product cycles.  Many smaller sites around the country answer to their divisions massive headquarters.  The management at the "top" cannot adequately lead because of the geographic and often cultural differences between sites.

review_title: Very Interesting Work But Corporate Red Tape and Security Can Be A Drag
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Raytheon has some very interesting projects to work on if you can wait a year or so for security clearances to start coming in.  The work can be highly technical and there are opportunities to publish or patent ideas, which the company rewards monetarily.
cons: The downside is that because the projects are classified, groups within the company are isolated and the opportunities for expanding your network are limited.  Promotions seem to occur automatically every other year until you become an E3 or E4 then it becomes competitive with other people in your group and even if you are filling the role of an E5 or E6, you will not be promoted unless there are fewer people at that level in your section and you are outperforming them.

review_title: A great place to be a contributor but management is clueless
pros: The salary is very good as are the benefits.  When given the opportunity to grow and develop as an employee, the options are there, but only to a point.  Very smart workforce, at least in Engineering, but most of the support areas there is a lot of nepotism, EEO promotions, and good old boy networks.
cons: The management is out of touch.  They don't relate to the work force, as many of them are only looking out for themselves or are very frightened when people under them do well, or are better respected then they are.  HR is useless.  They try to get you to work for Raytheon then abandon you as an employee.  Many long term employees get laid off or fired for little or no reason.  The Peter Principle is alive and well at Raytheon!

review_title: Three years later and NOTHING has changed!
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer I in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Haven't been laid off yet!
Latest program has a much better culture than previous program.
Competing company wants me now!
cons:
See "Older Women Engineers Not Respected," posted July 7, 2016
Same story as 3 years ago... Haven't been promoted in more than 10 years.
Served in progressively higher positions, but haven't received recognition or a significant increase in pay.
Functional management is inexperienced and untrained. 
If you try to advocate for yourself, you will be accused of being "difficult" or having "behavior issues" and black marked.
I work an average 20 hours overtime every week because my team is understaffed, is really young/green, requires lots of mentoring and coaching, and  doesn't work any extra hours because they all make more $$ than I do or are at a higher level. When I bring this up to functional managers, they blame me and say I don't know how to manage my team.
Fed up and ready to bolt even though only a few years away from drawing my early retirement pension!
The company's no retaliation stance is "FAKE! FAKE!, FAKE! FAKE!"
The company is plagued with sociopaths.

review_title: The good and the bad
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Woburn, MA
pros:
Job Security
 Numerous Positions
 Locations across US/worldwide
 Travel opportunities (only a maybe, and if you work for many, many years)
 Tuition reimbursement (but very limited and only for selected fields)
cons:
Arrogance of older employees 
 - ideas of younger employees considered a "waste of time"
 Bureaucracy
 Wait times 
 - a hurry up to wait around environment)
 Late nights/no notice 
 - meetings scheduled for after work hours, an hour before you are going home
 Knowledge Sharing 
 - Though older employees may have the knowledge, it is not generally shared with the younger generation
 Moving Positions 
 - this doesn't happen easily.
 Requirements on personal time
 Communication 
 - information does not get filtered down through the ranks (if you will)

review_title: Overall good place to work in Tucson
pros:
Get to work on cutting edge technologies that provide a critical need
Able to move around, self navigate, and work in different engineering functional groups as well as on different defense applications
Pays well, with recognition rewards getting better (as leadership pushes on this)
People do seem to care and want to work well with others
cons:
There is no other major engineering firms in Tucson, so it can seem like there is some "dead weight" that stays employed longer than they should (also since there is not much external local competition, wage growth is not super rapid, but the pay is  comparable at a national level)
Most activities are from government contracts which can make the pace slow at times (or also super busy)
Hard to get best capable engineers to move to Tucson since it's a small marketplace

review_title: Continuous Layoffs since 2009 - Fullerton
pros: Decent salary. Some managers are good to work for. 9/80 work schedule. VSP insurance.
cons: You are constantly wondering if you'll have a job in the next couple months, even if you are busy. Business development has had a hard time capturing new business. They focus on large programs only. Rounds of layoffs are on going. Morale is low and there is no focus on the employee. Apparently, even people with 20yrs experience in a specialized field are dispensable. Health benefits suck. $2000 deductibles for the only two options.

review_title: Too much red tape and bureaucracy, must be self-motivated to succeed here.
job_title: Multi-Disciplined Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Many different programs to choose from, good work-life balance, good compensation and benefits for work.
cons: Though there are a lot of programs, your ability to work on them depends solely on your relationship with your manager and your networking skills. If you are at all passive, you lose. You will not get approved for training opportunities, you will not be short-listed for interesting projects, you will not get promoted. The only one looking out for you is you.

review_title: anonymous former employee
pros: Stable work, solid benefits, company is slow to lay people off, ample time off, steady employment for most functions, good ethics for the most part, cool technology and a mission to be proud of, work life balance, decent business systems
cons: Mediocre management, slow to change, old white guys are just hanging on until retirement, HR is like junior high, no training dollars, promotions based on who likes you and who you know vs. competency, successful women are battle axes, matrix doesn't work, senior leaders are not held accountable for their selfish decisions and behaviors, good leadership is person, not role-based, a lot of people are just hanging on to get their pensions, ambition discouraged- IIS business is particularly dysfunctional, old office space like the 1980s

review_title: Good company to work for if you want an average career with above average pay
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer I in Aurora, CO
pros: One of the best reasons to work here is that there is absolutely no way to measure productivity.  If you're a slacker, it's hard for them to tell but if they ever do find out, you won't be fired, you'll just be moved to a different program.  Compensation is great though even with the discontinuing of profit sharing.
cons: If you actually care about doing a good job, and producing a quality product, you will get stuck fixing all of the lesser capable engineer's work.  The reward for good work is that you get to do other people's work and there's no accountability.  There is not much career potential unless you know the right people.  Promotions rarely ever happen above a Level 3 or Level 4.

review_title: Relatively secure place for a job, lousy place for a career
job_title: Senior Principal Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: People are generally nice. The company tries very hard to keep employees around even during the downturns in the defense and government markets.
cons: Low salaries, little room for advancement, highly political. Incredibly risk adverse limiting anything that might resemble innovation. Process and bureaucracy are the focus of 90% of every effort, making even the most simple things complicated, time consuming and expensive. Engineering approaches and tooling are decades old. Software is treated as a second class discipline to other engineering disciplines, despite the preponderance of software in all Raytheon systems.  This is the epitome of an old-school, stone-age company relying on outdated methodologies and political connections rather than evolving with the ever-changing and fast paced world of engineering. Employees are viewed and managed as cogs 0 treated as interchangeable metrics with little regard to their individual skills and expertise.

review_title: Raytheon, the best big company for people that value their family life.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Aurora, CO
pros: One of the few places I've worked that gives you good career opportunities,  nice benefits, flexible work hours without expecting you to work a 60 hour week.  They give you time to get your work done and have a life outside of work.  The time frames for assignments are longer which gives you time to do things right and to spend time on personal and professional development.  Benefits that I haven't seen since the early 90s.
cons: Raytheon is a large government contractor and as such has everything that goes along with that like a lot of management, and tedious processes.  You can feel like a cog because you are so isolated from upper management and their decisions. They tell you what is going on and ask for your input but don't expect to change any minds.

review_title: New to the company, it seems okay but not great.
job_title: Software Test Engineer in Aurora, CO
pros: It's a decent job for a big, stable company. They do a lot of military as well as unclassified work, so there's some opportunity to move around, laterally. You'll have an opportunity to get a security clearance doing that, so that's a help.  But there's never any time to review lessons learned, it's always just "on to the next project".
cons: Upper management seems to think we all care about quality, but middle management only cares about making the contract bonus. I'd love to do a better job, but when management bids an 18 month task to be done in 14 months, with a bonus if it's done in 12 months, well guess what? It's done (poorly) in 12 months.

review_title: Raythen has been good to me and is a well paying job with countless perks! They pay you more for education and certs!!!
pros: THere are so many oppurtunties to excel you just need to apply yourself and seek further education.  They have given me money to relocate, travel and have paid for my experiance in the military.  I was shocked that they considered me for the job and have given my all to work hard and move up in the company.  If i ever get tired of this job I can simply apply for another job and they will move me.  Communication is great in my matrix and they have gone above and beyond for me and my familiy.  I would ecomend them to any of my fco-workers
cons: The managment and change process is slow but effective

review_title: Process Intensive
pros:
The work you do has a direct impact on the nation and its security. You feel good that you did more than "just earn a paycheck". 

You will work on things that people in the commercial world would never even think of. 

Great benefits, especially flextime and 9/80 weeks, flex time.
cons:
Very process intensive. Some of the processes are over the top. If you want to be promoted, learn the processes. It is actually more imponrtant to understand process rather than actually "know" how to do something.

Development (R&D) is everything. Normal IT is not as valued. 

Some incompetent people should be let go. 

Putting up the government bureacracy can be very frustrating.  

You are at the whims of the congressional budget.

The business politics often have the business units fighting with each other.

review_title: Good company, few advancement opportunities
job_title: Senior Manufacturing Engineer II in Dallas, TX
pros: Surrounded by very professional and talented people, very few managers micromanage, technical challenges daily.  Pay and benefits are pretty much competitive (if on the lower side of industry averages) so this keeps a lot of employees from leaving the company.
cons: Overall a good company to work for, but if you want to advance you will need to search and apply for new jobs in the company since very few managers help you out in this regard.  In the last year the company has had multiple layoffs causing a very stressful workplace.  It was especially discouraging that some good employees were chosen to be laid off over others that appear to be part of the "good ol' boy network".

review_title: Interesting work but sexist when it comes to pay
job_title: Mechanical Engineer II in Tewksbury, MA
pros: The work is interesting and fun. Good benefits. 9/80 work weeks
cons:
I found out I was being paid only $1-2k more than male new college hires when I had been working there 3 years. Same thing happened to two other women I worked with. When bringing sexism up to management nothing happens. I didn’t even get any feedback, much less any change. The sexism is pretty clear. They also don’t pay enough for the cost of living in Massachusetts in general.

It’s impossible to get fired here. I heard a man talking on the phone in his cube say something extremely racist. After reporting to management and HR, there didn’t seem to be any punishment.

review_title: A lot worse places to work.
pros: The job security is great.  You can probably do below average work forever and never have to worry about getting axed because it would be too much of a hassle.  However, the people in my specific department are competent and definately seem to know what they are doing.  Co-workers are friendly and respectful.  From what I hear though, different business segments of Ray can have a completely different working environment.  Luck definately plays a part!
cons: After looking around, the pay seems to be a little below average but too late now I guess.  There is a clear generation gap between the older generation that are reaching retirement age in the company and the new wave of young professionals coming in.  I don't know if sometimes the older people are afraid too talk to me or just think they're too good...

review_title: Working at Raytheon NCS
pros: Potential of opportunities to work on Defense for the United States. Very Good Health Coverage.
cons:
Very delayed and inaccurate feedback on performance. It appears to be that Program and Project Management have unwritten criteria that their dissatisfaction is to be voiced to the employee officially as "we are over budget", then to the employees department supervision as "very dissatisfied with performance." 
A worst case scenario is to meet the employee in the hall and tell them verbally, that they were correct is their assesment and results, but be unwilling to correct their official input. 
Ironically, the program personnel will use your results and output to advance their program. If my results were unsatisfactory, then why would you use them and have me update them?

review_title: Stay away if you're not technical.
pros: They have flexible hours.  They have multiple job openings and you can transfer between divisions.
cons:
1. Strictly referring to the SAS division in a non-technical position, I saw little room for growth and advancement. 
2. They want employees to be overqualifed before they are considered for new positions.  
3. The cultural environement was unfriendly with a serious lack of respect for employees.
4. They will make promises to new hires and have no issues breaking these promises once the employee starts working.
5. The poor management style and unfairness of the leadership team promoted a lack of trust among employees.

review_title: Raytheon is an excellent place to work and learn for student interns.
pros: I would recommend doing an internship with Raytheon over the summer because you will get real work to do, you will not just file papers and make copies.  Also, Raytheon offers an excellent intern program where you are exposed to all of the various business functions and what they do.  Very good for students!
cons: As far I can see, I did not have any bad experiences at  my summer internship.  All of the employees were very nice to me and always willing to help me.  I would say the biggest con for me is just the commute and the traffic on the way to work.

review_title: Very good company to work for
job_title: Systems Administrator in Fort Irwin, CA
pros: Very good mid-level management, they work with you to do the best job for the customer.
cons: top management tend to treat the lower employees like they give little value to the company. yet we are the people that the customer work one on one with every day.

review_title: Raytheon, Aurora CO
pros: Salary seems to pretty good and the employees are moral and ethical.  Onsite gym and cafeteria. Plenty of work to do. Free coffee and tea.
cons: It has embraced diversity. If you use the gym you will likely be in the locker room with someone of the opposite sex who is confused about their gender. If you are a senior engineer you will be sitting in a 10'X10' cube with 2-3 other people.  They are moving to a DevOps type seating arrangements so in the near future the seating will be similar to a call center structure.  They removed the profit sharing that other Raytheon business units have. IIS is now a "services" company. Employees are now treated like contractors.

review_title: Great Accounting organization, but tons of red tape if you want to move up
pros: The accounting organization is second to none in terms of knowledge and being proactive to stay ahead of issue, rule changes, etc. They do recognize good, hard workers with achievement awards. Business segments get every other Friday off if they work 9 hours/day, Corporate gets 1/2 day Friday's in the summer if they work 9 hours/day. Work-life balance is excellent for such a large accounting organization.
cons: HR red tape is awful. Promotions within your current role are nearly impossible, have to hope a higher level job opens up and that you are qualified for it. US Government budget troubles have hurt the company in terms of things like employee recognition events.

review_title: Engineer
job_title: Electrical Engineer II in Sudbury, MA
pros: I worked there for 17 years.  Although this only applies in my situation I will get a pension and that's for putting the time in, something unheard of these days and no longer offered as a benefit.  Also started my 401k there and did well (more for my own choices)
cons: I had convinced myself with all the negatives with this company maybe this was a boot camp situation and things would get better.  As I realized where my future was headed down a dead end street I decided anything would be an improvement.  My goal was always to do work but more times than not get caught up in elementary school foolishness.  The section and department managers have their immediate circle of friends and you are either in the club or not considered a team player.

review_title: Good company should be getting even better with the merger
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Good teamwork among individual contributors.
New CEO sounds like he will make positive changes to the company where needed.
8/90 work schedule is great, having every other Friday off.
Many managers are happy to let you transition roles, as long as it is beneficial to the company as a whole. But you will need to do your own networking, research, and legwork into what is available.
The mentoring program and Employee Resource Groups are very valuable.
cons:
Middle management can be difficult to work with, although not everywhere.
There is a mentality that only engineers can do program management work.
Finding a work/life balance can be difficult to find unless you are firm with setting boundaries.

review_title: Bad place to work for supply chain professionals
job_title: Supply Chain in El Segundo, CA
pros: Decent pay compared to industry average.  Allows 9/80 schedule for some employees.  A large network of professionals, I'm really just typing words to meet the minimum requirement now
cons: Almost everyone in the Supply Chain Management (SCM) organization is over-worked and stressed out.  This is due not only to a high workload but mainly because of terrible processes, procedures and tools for SCM employees to do their jobs.  There is a major disconnect between what SCM upper management thinks its employees can do (and have access to) vs. what they can really do.  The other functions (engineering, finance, operations) have absolutely no respect for the SCM role or its employees.

review_title: Hard to believe the reviews
pros: 9/80 schedule. Every other Friday off.
cons: I'm at year 25 of my career and worked across 6 companies.  Raytheon was the worst and I’m thankful that I was able to get out quickly. I'm convinced most of these reviews are fake. Morale across all divisions are the lowest I've seen. RMS seems to have the most unhappy people, but you’ll be hard pressed to find anyone who likes the company. The section heads and managers at RMS are the worst I've seen throughout my 25 year career. If you're not in the "boys-club" or a white male then it’s darn near impossible to get rated correctly at review time and you get a lousy raise. Bosses lie to keep the people they don't like down. It happens across divisions but seems much worse at RMS. The only people who move up are the ones who know someone or were designated a "hi-pot" by a friend in upper management. Most of these hi-pot’s are hacks and lie about what they do. The employees who've been wronged are afraid to say anything. When they do HR comes against the person who reported the wrongdoer to HR.

review_title: Don't expect to be promoted fast, common to be E3 for 20 years
pros: Compartmentalized security clearance makes you more marketable in defense industry. If you are software engineer, programmer, computer science major, mathematician, physicist, you'll be well sought after at this site.
cons:
No growth path for technical oriented people. Slow promotion.  A big problem is that you see fairly common people with 15-20 years of experience doing good work continue to be E3 where in other defense companies they would be E4 already.  

Serious communication problem at the senior management level.  Senior management lacks trust in their senior technical folks.  Decisions are managed via a strict chain of command hierarchy.  Among management level, it seems status is everything (ie. who has the biggest office).

review_title: Beat Down Already
job_title: Mfg. Manager I in McKinney, TX
pros: Typical large firm, rather stable but set in their ways.  Decent benefits, and pay.  Being large much potential for different assignments, especially if you are an engineer, a vet, a minority or a female.  I am none of these.   Providing quality defense products to our men & women in  the Armed Forces is the only reason I'm still there.
cons: Unusual culture, have heard statements like "job on the line" even when the issue is clearly out of your control.  Bureaucracy is as expected at a large company, it's made worse when you are sitting across a table from people with 40, 35, or 30 year service pins.  Don't expect to make any quick changes and as mentioned above especially if you are not an Engineer or Vet or a Female or a Minority.

review_title: Solid place to work;Stodgy culture
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros:
- Pays well
- The benefits are very good
- Stable organizational structure
- Large company, so it's easy to move around to new areas
- Profit sharing  is good
cons:
- Stodgy culture
- Due to the nature of the business there is an underlying culture of paranoia and security concerns
- Also, the culture isn't exactly fun. In fact, if you are having fun at work, you can be seen as goofing off. Everything is taken very seriously even when not necessary
- Lots of former military folks also contribute to the culture
- Very conservative when it comes to picking technology. It's a big ship and they do not move quickly. They still use Lotus Notes as email client, for instance
- Wholly dependent on government funding and contracts which can lead to some job insecurity

review_title: greed rules
pros: Ten years ago I would have had something put here.
cons:
This company used to strive to be the "Employer of Choice". Now they strive to be average, because average is cheaper.

Because Raytheon has acquired businesses, there are many different retirement plans.  Mine had a pension accrual rate increase between the ages of 53 and 56.  They laid me off at age 53. 

I was told that I was being laid off because of work slow down.  I looked at the spreadsheet my organization uses to track workload.  There was more work than there was people to do it. This is backed up by the fact that my former organization opened new job listings, with exactly the same skill requirements has the position I had before my severance period ended.  (And no, they did not seek to recall me.)

Every employee has to take a class annually that reminds us to be ethical.  Do you think the above reflects an ethical company?

review_title: Raytheon is a great place to work - high tech, lots of opportunities, growing quickly
pros: Working on important missions for global defense.   Cool technologies and an extremely wide variety.  Fairly easy to move explore different roles and work on different projects.  Decisions are typically made through good engineering judgement and often formal trade studies as opposed to the opinion of some exec.  Big company (~65000) with lots of opportunities and growing quickly.
cons: Big company and it is easy to get lost.  Trying to embrace agile but still struggling to let go of waterfall.  Many platforms need to stay in service for decades so sometime need to deal with older technology.

review_title: No the greatest place - more like govt work
pros: Flexible work hours - folks are allowed to work from home on Mondays and Fridays which helps on the cost of commuting into the office.  Everyone is equipped with the latest laptop and docking station which gives lets you move around.  THe office has wifi connectivity as well.  The benefits are really good and the company offers some good perks as well such as discounts to local entertainment venues.
cons: With all of the flexibility in working from home there is an extreme lack of teamwork here.  Its obvious that not a lot can get accomplished in the 3 days of folks being in the office.  Projects seem to take a very long time to complete.  Folks don't seem to have the same sense of urgency.  Its a lot like working for the government in that it is very slow and bureaucratic.

review_title: Come here to learn and launch your career - but leave before you're fully assimilated.
pros: Very mature processes and systems related to employee and career development.  You are able to work on projects that matter and that keep soldiers alive and our nation secure.  Raytheon does a very good job connecting your day to day work with the strategic direction of the company.
cons: Extremely political - if the boss likes you, then that's all that's required.  Creates an environment where 'kissing up and kicking down' is actually encouraged (though I don't believe this is on purpose).  VPs feel as if their word is law and are confused when someone dares to differ in their opinion - they are surprisingly disconnected from the working lives of their staff, but feel as if they're in the loop.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: Been working here less than a year so far but it has been great. Everybody is very helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly. Training was done very well, started learning technical stuff on day one, which hasn't always been the case starting somewhere new. Also great that it is a salaried position while still paying overtime worked (normal time though, not time and a half). For most salaried engineering positions it seems it's a 40 hour minimum work week, often more. Here, you are not expected to work any more than 40 hours a week, and if you do you will be compensated at your normal rate. Hours are also extremely flexible, and the 9/80 work week schedule is awesome but you still have the option to do regular 5/40 weeks if you prefer it.
cons: Have to get a security clearance, process can be annoying but they do pay you for your time spent filling out all the forms.

review_title: OK company in a boring location
pros: This is a very large division of a large company.  There are lots of opportunities to do lots of different things, especially if you are an engineer.  People are generally treated fairly and it is hard to complain about the 9/80 work week.  Overtime is not generally expected, and Tucson is a good place to raise a family.
cons: Advancement and raises are based as much on who you know and how long you have been in your current position than how competent you are.  It is easy to get lost in the crowd if you don't know how to take control of your career.  The city of Tucson can be oppressively hot in the summer and doesn't really have a lot of activities to keep childless people occupied.

review_title: Marking time until I could find a better job
job_title: Senior Principal Software Engineer in Portsmouth, RI
pros:
Benefits have been good (but are getting worse)
There are good opportunities to work with others and outside your comfort zone
There are many opportunities for travel
Program capture is the most visible/rewarded job
cons:
Very little credit for technical expertise, or opportunity for professional development unless it is a critical technology area for the business (e.g., radar)
Nobody is going to look out for your career. Your managers are competing with you for better assignments
Creativity in general is going to frustrate you, not reward you. Do not work outside the box. Covering your bosses ass is the way to get rewarded

review_title: Great work/life balance, good benefits, somewhat stagnant business scope
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Tewksbury, MA
pros:
I believe Raytheon consistently delivers more technically sound engineering solutions than our competitors.  Unfortunately, we historically lack shrewd business sense, which has, at times, cost us contracts.  A recent change over in senior management seems to be actively working to improve the company in this area.

A great opportunity to work in a variety of roles across all aspects of the business.  The company actively encourages professional growth and allows employees flexibility for their personal needs.
cons: Business scope is often limited by the nature of this industry.  Raytheon is primarily known as a missile and radar company.  We have tried to expand our repertoire some, but it is often an uphill battle to get people in the company to stretch beyond our company's core competency.

review_title: Weak in training and salary reviews, keep retirement event secret
job_title: Senior Design and Verification Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Interesting and challenging work in the design and verification of electronics.
cons:
1) Very tight control over finances, and that translates to a) poor salary reviews, b) very little (almost none) opportunities to attend technical seminars/conventions, c) reluctant (and slow) to adopt new advanced  methodologies.
2)There is an untold bias toward older employees, and that means less raises as you mature.  I made the mistake of advertising my retirement date, and that led to ZERO raise. 
3) Reading he Glassdoor reviews, I can see that things have NOT changed much since I retired. Same old politics, tightening of the belt.  
4) Still in the technical field, I still don't see Raytheon employees at technical seminars that address the latest technologies.

review_title: Military Contract Employment
pros: The  pay is fantastic if you can handle living on a military base in a conflict area.  Home office support is pretty good.  I enjoyed the training week prior to deployment and the people I met there.
cons: There is very little support for program managers to follow through with disciplinary measures.  The company is afraid to get sued.  It's frustrating to have your hands tied by a PMO half way around the world, in addition to being unable to remove employees from your program that have no business being there.  As with most military contract companies, "boots on the ground" equals money.  Employee/program well being is not a high priority.  No career advancement here really. No surprise here, if you are hired as a contract employee you are a contract employee.  There may be some mobility within the program you are hired for, but to move into a position at Raytheon is very rare.

review_title: Great Benefits
pros: The benefits package offered is by far one of the best in the city. Most employees are fairly compensated for the job they perform, particularly those employees just out of college. In most areas/departments, there is a sense of pride and teaming atmosphere. No doubt a result of the "close knit, family working conditions."
cons: There is definately a "glass ceiling" of sorts and a "good ole boy" mentality, particularly in organizations with a high percentage of middle aged white males. Some of the newer employees spend more time kissing up to leadership then they do meeting work committments. Unfortunately, those are the same individuals that rank high during performance appraisal time, and receive the larger raises. Upward mobility is stifiled.

review_title: Raytheon - A Great Technology Company With Great Engineers
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Falls Church, VA
pros: Raytheon company consists of innovative technology, very competent engineers, a reasonable flexible work schedule, and a good work/life balance.  The benefits on the whole seem to be fairly comparable to others in the defense contractor industry in which they compete but I believe they could be better.  Several of my former Raytheon colleagues have departed for better pay at other large defense contractors.  I believe overall compensation could be improved in my opinion and would result in better employee retention.  Aside from the slightly below average compensation, in my opinion, Raytheon still remains a good place to work and I would still recommend it as a good company for other engineers to work at.
cons: Occasionally, feel like you get lost in the crowd because it is such a large company.  No other complaints that come to mind.

review_title: Raytheon SAS El Segundo
job_title: Electrical Engineer I Intern in El Segundo, CA
pros: The best reasons to work for Raytheon SAS would be for the pay, location, and if you don't want to work hard.  I worked in LA where it never rains and is always sunny.  The company offers flex time so you get every other friday off.  Also if you aren't a early person, you can come in later and stay later.
cons: The downsides of working at Raytheonn SAS is you aren't challenged at all.  You don't see much of your manager.  My manager was in a seperate building and didn't have any engineering experience.  If you aren't  a go getter and don't take charge of your career you can get left behind in this huge company.

review_title: Micromanagement and metrics rule
pros: Fairly liberal in accomodating needs, good pay, flexible schedule, opportunities for growth, stable work, multiple locations so you can live almost anywhere in the greater Boston area and work here.
cons: Matrix organization results in multiple bosses all wanting highlights, financial status, plans, metrics, and presentations.  In fact the reporting  and financial control process takes up more time than the work.  Limited training due to overhead budget contraints, no formal new hire mentoring and training.  Extremely limited professional development opportunities due to low overhead budgets.  Every high performer is overloaded with work, and there skaters do nothing but are rewarded due to politics.

review_title: Maybe a good place to start but not to stay long term
pros: You learn a lot about the defense industry if you move around the company, there are many locations throughout the world. Benefits are pretty good as well as work life balance.
