cons: Unless you come in at a high salary, your chances of making any money here are slim to none. Promotions barely get you an additional 5% increase. Obtaining higher education will not give you an advantage amongst others. There are far too many layers of management and I always felt like I was being micromanaged. The company really likes mediocre employees who will do what they ask and not ask questions  - the smart ones can see there is no future with the company and get out before it's too late.

review_title: Maybe a good place to start but not to stay long term
pros: You learn a lot about the defense industry if you move around the company, there are many locations throughout the world. Benefits are pretty good as well as work life balance.
cons: Unless you come in at a high salary, your chances of making any money here are slim to none. Promotions barely get you an additional 5% increase. Obtaining higher education will not give you an advantage amongst others. There are far too many layers of management and I always felt like I was being micromanaged. The company really likes mediocre employees who will do what they ask and not ask questions  - the smart ones can see there is no future with the company and get out before it's too late.

review_title: Headed in wrong direction
pros:
The paycheck never bounced. I was never shot at. It is hard to find 20 words positive for this company.
Some smart people work there. Was there almost 8 years, and it got worse every year. 
If you are someone just out of college, and have a choice, definitely avoid this one.
cons:
Company is so focused on process and schedule that there literally is no "fun". No enjoyment of an engineering career. Way too many people solely focused on earned value metrics. Not enough actual workers. So what does mangement do? They lay off workers (engineers). 
Also, making "diversity" such an important goal that you are actually expected to "celebrate" the lifesyle of people you don't agree with. This does not belong at work. This has nothing to do with products, it is just a feel good thing that gives some parasitic manager(s) a paycheck for dubious rewards. Just require that at work you have to respect everyone. Problem solved.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: Raytheon is one of the best places I have ever worked. The management truly strives to employ people who care about what they do and want to produce the best work possible. This passion is infectious. Collaboration across departments and offices is encouraged, and the quality of the work shows what you can accomplish when you work together. Best of all, the compensation is fair, so I never felt like I was being paid peanuts for the amount of effort I put into the job. Overall, a great place to work.
cons: It's difficult for me to find any cons. Some people may be turned off by working overtime, and there were a few times that I had to in order to meet a deadline. This didn't bother me at all. The company is also very strict in following the rules, which to me is positive, but I guess some people may think that is unreasonable?

review_title: Take The Good With The Bad
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Fullerton, CA
pros: Flexible time off.  Not much penalty for doing a mediocre job. (see corresponding comment below)  There is not much change either good or bad.  The job that you need to do to get a good review is pretty well defined.  The people are normal, descent people.
cons: Not much reward for doing a great job.  (see corresponding comment above)  I find it very boring.  It seems to be impossible to get a promotion unless you are a member of the chosen few.  It's not based on your actual performance, more on how much people like you.  It just kind of stays the same and as long as nothing rocks the boat.  Alot of teh technology is pretty outdated and will make you less valuable in the marketplace.

review_title: Poor culture for outgoing individuals, excellent opportunities for growth
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Tucson, AZ
pros: Coworkers tend to have tons of experience and know how with their work. I am very young (started here right out of my undergraduate degree) and have generally felt I've been surrounded by very intelligent people. The people you're surrounded with are generally very helpful, when they choose to be, and are good individuals. It's been heavily emphasized from the get-go that I need to get an advanced degree to move up. If you get plugged in with the right group of people, i can easily see this place being a wonderful place to work. The atmosphere is pretty cut throat, and is inspiring if you have the drive to succeed. If you have a lot of independent drive, you will build a network that will help you reach success. You need to be willing to put yourself out there (and risk falling flat on your face) to grow, which is challenging but is good. Need to consistently seek out opportunities. I generally feel in control of what I get to work on. Taking time off work is almost NEVER a problem as long as you flex your hours, use PTO, and complete work on time - a flexible schedule is absolutely wonderful, not to mention every other Friday off! Benefits are great too.
cons: The people are generally nice and helpful, but most of all keep to themselves with their work and socially. Relationships at work aren't ever really built up and business is the primary driver (which can be good and bad, but I think a little more balance would be good). The culture is what would be expected at any engineering company - a lot of the people are very very reserved when engaging at meetings or communicating with each other which makes understanding what to do very difficult. Unless directed so by someone higher than them, more often than not people would come off as reluctant to help. Middle management is pretty awful at guiding new hires in their jobs, they just expect you to sink or swim. There is a massive gap in knowledge between new hires and most of the existing employees, with a culture that seemingly suppresses any attempt to eliminate this great divide. Also, the structure for performance reviews is awful and is set up to fail unless you devote a significant amount of time 'bragging' to your superior about your accomplishments; you'd think such a large, successful corporation would have a more defined performance evaluation cycle in place that would lead people to success. Often times I can see people getting in a rut if they don't actively communicate work to their functional supervisors, and easily getting complacent with what they do. The program I am on is rife with politics which aggravates the hell out of me, but I've heard it's not as bad as other companies.

review_title: RMS is a great place to work with tons of opportunities for career growth
pros: RMS is willing to take a chance on fresh talent. I started with less than a year of industry experience, and received more than fair compensation. There is tons of opportunity for growth and to hone in on exactly what you want from your career. They don’t expect you to know everything; as long as you show you are giving 100% in the tasks given to you, you will be given respect and higher mobility when more opportunities arise.
cons: Unfortunately, because its a defense contractor, a great deal of your job will involve government contracts and info you won’t have access to right away. This often leads to disconnects or poor communication between workers and team leads, or across disciplines.

review_title: Not a great place to start a career.
pros:
Flexible work schedule and great benefits.

You can slack off and nobody cares (I see this as a con but many out there consider this a pro).
cons:
As a young EE I wanted opportunities to learn and grow from on the job experience. Raytheon is not a great place for this. Project progression is extremely slow, so much so that other engineers joke about how little progress we make each week. Some engineers have a "that's not my job" mentality so responsibility for certain parts of projects will get passed around via email until everyone forgets about it.

Performance reviews are not based on performance so if you are hired on as anything less than senior, then you are the scapegoat because managers are highly encouraged to give out good, neutral, and bad reviews.

You will be shamed for having innovative ideas. Raytheon is conservative when it comes to design work, always opting to reuse old tech.

review_title: Interns get full benefits
pros: Good starting salary.  Reimbursement for educational expenditures.  Job stability - no layoffs.  Interns get full benefits; this includes paid vacation, 401k matching, and insurance.  Intern pay is based solely on academic level: incoming freshman - $15 / hour ; incoming sophomore - $17 / hour ; incoming junior - $22 / hour ; incoming senior $25 / hour.  Starting salaries are based on a formula including what school your degree is from, what GPA you have, and what experience you have.  Minority status also seems to be included.  Former interns are given job offer preference, but they are not given higher starting salaries than other people.
cons: Low salary growth.  Insignificant promotion raises.  You get paid more if you start off with a masters degree than if you earn one while working at Raytheon.

review_title: More Bureaucracy, less productivity
pros: Some projects have cutting edge technology, but few and far between. Good pay, good benefits, and mostly good people. Allows people to be professionally mobile and rotate between disciplines, programs, and geographical locations.
cons: Extremely burdensome bureaucracy, rules and processes seem to prevent creativity, individuality and productivity.  Real engineering is becoming a minority capability. Company used to be managed by seasoned engineers, but these have mostly been placed by dictatorship minded finance and MBA types.

review_title: Has been pretty good though I am interested in the next step and have had some trouble finding it.
pros: Large, stable company with diverse markets.  Friendly people (mostly).   Flexibility to move around to different roles internally.  Good benefits with decent understanding of work life balance.
cons: Large company - can be challenging to earn recognition and career growth.  As a high performer their is little inventive (beyond your own work ethic) to continue being a high performer.  Literally all options for advancement seem to be "a lateral move" as far as compensation is concerned, which can discourage a good work ethic.

review_title: It is a Job
pros: - Good pay - good benefits - pension plan - 401k-
cons:
This place is a cesspool 
- In IADC its a factory where the number of derelicts numbers in the hundreds. The management style is who  can yell the loudest . the big bully mentality still exists 
- Try not to use the restrooms , they are filthy and I have seen better in a gas station.
- They say they have a 9/80 schedule, but in Andover they have cancelled it - No word when it will be back

review_title: Sr. Systems Engineer
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Garland, TX
pros: The company pays well and there are a lot of locations you can choose to work.  They are starting to put some money into improved facilities but that is coming at the expense of the employees.
cons: They cant win big contracts, if your contract dies they wont carry you on overhead for any amount of time, they will make you burn PTO or take no pay.  Many of their facilities should be shut down because they are so out dated.  They are too big to care about the employee.  You are just a number there.

review_title: Good start, get what you need and go.
pros: Great place to launch a career.  Good exposure to technology.
cons:
The culture does not have very much freedom.  Felt like I was serving a prison sentence while working there.  What isadvertised should be changed to discretionary by management because that is who really decided on everything.  Management should not penalize or take it personally when employees leave their organizations.  They have a habit of publicly berating and exclusion like I have never seen before.  Yet they advertise, "you are in control of your career."  When you do take control, management will badmouth you to the rest of the organization in order to deter anyone else from doing the same. 
Management through fear and intimidation is not good for any business.

review_title: Good place to start your career, but growth is quickly limited
pros: Raytheon offers good job security, benefits, flexibility, and entry level opportunities. There are also interesting opportunities for international travel and assignments.
cons: People tend to get stuck doing in the same role for many years and it is very difficult to change roles and get new experiences, which causes a lack of motivation. Bureaucracy makes it difficult to get even menial tasks done. The HR cycle and performance review process doesn't make any sense and your engineering "level' does not at all correspond to your actual role in the company (entry level engineers do the same tasks as senior and principal engineers). Training and development courses are almost non-existent.

review_title: Ok place to work
pros: The benefits are good and I love having the 9/80 Fridays. Pay is also pretty good to a couple other places I've worked at.
cons: Management is not at great is they could be, I think us people at the bottom get treated like we are in the bottom. Everywhere you look almost everyone either there father or mother works for the company, best Way to get hired here us if your related to someone. I Can't stand the politics and culture here and management are never open to new ideas even though They day the opposite. Don't know How but alot of the lazy people who do absolutely nothing get promoted alot out here I guess if you know the right people this is the company for you...

review_title: Some good, some bad.  Come in as an early career HRG, and you'll be okay.
job_title: Principal Human Resources Generalist in Tucson, AZ
pros: Pay seems to be at or above market.  Raytheon is a big player in the defense industry, so you'll get to know it well.  If you're an early career HR professional, this may be a great place to stay for a few years to get some experience.
cons: Antiquated performance management philosophy, no real HR innovation. You're graded against your peers in order to get a raise, so no real incentive to collaborate with other HR people.  Incredibly tactical, administrative HR function focused only on deadlines, not on process improvements.

review_title: Entitlement
pros: The working level of people at Raytheon Missile Systems is great.
cons: The leadership of Raytheon Missile Systems from the CEO through all 30+ vice presidents and assistant vice presidents operates out of a sense of entitlement.  They are entitled to their extravagant parties,  entitled to fly first class, entitled to free lunch and entitled to a bunch of people around them who never tell them they are doing anything wrong because if you do, there will be retaliation.   They are bad business men who allow senior program managers and leaders to run amuck with New Business Investment funds, spending mostly on travel with no resulting new business and no consequence.  They have way too many people and could be producing better profits or better growth for the company by slashing the head count and trimming the non-productive.  Then they would not have that crowd around them telling them how brilliant they all are.

review_title: IIS vs SAS
job_title: Software Engineer II in McKinney, TX
pros:
I moved from SAS division to IIS division within Raytheon which I shouldnt have done.

SAS - Worked with really interesting work. Very laid back atmosphere. Great management. Learned a lot since the program I worked on required SW engineers to help with everything from requirements to testing. 
IIS - Plenty of opportunities to move around since they needed a lot of people in all departments.
cons:
SAS - Not a lot of opportunities to move up and gain more responsibilities. Technology and SW methodologies used to develop systems was very outdated and could end up pigeon holing your career.
IIS - Much more strict. Micromanaged everything.

review_title: Be Very Careful Where You Tread
pros: Excellent place to work, only if you're under a good and honest management.
cons: I received my 25 year recognition, 3 achievement awards and my layoff notice all in the same year.  There's no company loyalty.  Management positions tend to be filled by the good ole boy system rather than earned by experience or knowledge.  Thus there's (and sometimes vindictive) morons are running the show.  HR is not there to help the employees, it exists only to protect the company.   They promote "see something, say something" is all for show, since doing so can get you tossed out the door.

review_title: Break your back for Finance Mgrs
pros: Good pay, sometimes you won’t have to work weekends...
cons: Horrible hours, have to explain why you charged each hour of your day to certain programs being ran/managed by finance majors and not engineers, no room or opportunity to be innovative and progress manufacturing processes, bandaid solutions for everything, all OPS management does is go to meetings that make them feel more important than the people pushing their product out, then they go demand everything be done after and cheaper.

review_title: Break your back for Finance Mgrs
pros: Good pay, sometimes you won’t have to work weekends...
cons: Horrible hours, have to explain why you charged each hour of your day to certain programs being ran/managed by finance majors and not engineers, no room or opportunity to be innovative and progress manufacturing processes, bandaid solutions for everything, all OPS management does is go to meetings that make them feel more important than the people pushing their product out, then they go demand everything be done after and cheaper.

review_title: Good But Slow
job_title: Mixed Signal Design Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros:
* 40 hour work weeks
* Cool and unique projects that you can't talk to anyone about
* You get to work on missiles
* Some nice people to get to know and work with
cons:
* Red tape government type of work ... extremely slow
* Friends that graduated with you will be way ahead in technical proficiency by year five in commercial industries. This place is incredibly slow
* Promotion given on years served versus merit. 
* Inefficiency is how it's done here. Red tape everywhere. Management loves process to no end. 
* Managers are you ... five-ten years ago. No experience or know how-to's in managing. 
* No learning/training opportunities besides what you learn ... if anything ... on the job.

review_title: Better work life balance than other high tech companies but the company has very low profit margins
job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer II in Dallas, TX
pros: 9/80 schedule. Work life balance. Free dental. Nice coworkers. Developing tools for our soldiers is a perk. Weeks and half at Christmas.
cons:
Company is going to tiny cubes and open concept. Even managers don’t have a private space. Managements is very stingy and cheap due to low profit margins I suspect. Seating arrangement is isolating. They should allow similar job functions to sit together. 

“On your own time” policy is ridiculous and limits collaboration and learning. 

As with a lot of companies, lower level management is terrified of upper management and over reacts to every automated system ding we get. They have created too many processes and systems to manage our work. I think they will get burned by smaller, more nimble companies.

review_title: Raytheon: A comfortable place to work
job_title: Business Development in El Segundo, CA
pros: Raytheon is a very easy and safe place to work.  If an individual enjoys a slow and comfortable pace of work they will enjoy working at Raytheon.  The company is not the best place for an ambitious high achiever.  The flexible work schedule (9/80) and ample time off are nice.  In general employees are treated with respect.  Lots of opportunities for growth in the future given the aging work force.
cons: Slow pace of work and advancement.  There can be a glass ceiling in certain functional areas if you do not have a military background or engineering background.  Working with the government is slow and not very interesting.  Your counterparts on the government side are often not up to par in terms of their overall intellect and talent.

review_title: Typical Defense Company
pros:
Challenging work
Variety of programs and technologies
Lateral and upward mobility opportunities
Great people
Location (must like Southern California)
Flexible work schedule opportunities
cons:
Location (Southern California is expensive)
Overly constrained by procesess
Poorly rolled out and coordinated engineering initiatives
"War on Talent" HR Practices (look what happened to Enron!)

review_title: The ideal job until management mis-steps
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Garland, TX
pros:
Direct-report supervisors are great.
Appreciated professionalism of my co-workers. Great to work with them.
Flexible schedules allow work-life balance, but there is a penalty for taking advantage of them.
Paid time off between Christmas and New Years.
People identified as high-potential can expect to see encouragement and support from management in terms of career advancement.
cons:
Can not trust communication from Upper management.
People other than "high-pots" may be limited in career advancement, though immediate supervisors may provide support. Raytheon has a policy of rotating upper management from site to site, and there has been less promotion from within.
Nepotism is alive and well.
No windows

review_title: Large engineering-focused company with strong leadership but a lot of middle management
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros:
Flexible 9/80 work schedule (every other Friday off)
Great team and boss
Current team is very flat organizationally so a lot of exposure to leadership
Opportunities to work on exciting and challenging projects and assignments
A big emphasis on learning, diversity, etc.
Pretty good benefits
cons:
Sometimes too much bureaucracy to deal with so great ideas can get lost in the mix
It takes a while for "change" to take place because the company is so large
Very engineering-focused, which can sometimes be a challenge for non-engineering functions

review_title: Poor Culture and Overall Benefits not Close to Industry Leaders
pros:
Decent Salary
Opportunity to get / upgrade clearance
cons:
Terrible Work-Life Balance
Expectation to do some mandatory training on personal time
Expectation to attend some all-hands meetings on personal time
Terrible PTO rollover policy of 40 hours maximum into the next calendar year... Those hours must be used by August otherwise they will disappear
No Sick Leave Benefits (considered part of PTO)
False advertising on relo benefits.... did not get relo benefits nor sign on bonus even though job posting was advertised with relo benefits
Expectation of getting CISSP on my own time when employer will eventually require me to have it

review_title: Great stable, if not always challenging, place to work
job_title: Software Engineer II in Garland, TX
pros: They pay is great, the work is sometimes interesting, and your co-workers will be intelligent.  You'll be working on something you can be proud of.  The company will pay for you to continue your education, which is great if your interested in getting a free graduate degree.
cons: Not always working on the latest and greatest technology.  Sometimes feel like your re-inventing the same wheel just to sell it to the Government.  You get very little feedback ever.  There are some politics that go on (I suppose that is normal) in that it seems like promotions are often determined by who you know.  The software engineering positions can be really boring.  Software engineers are often treated as replaceable parts that can be moved around at will.  Sometimes they shove process down your throat and don't let you take ownership of what you're working on.

review_title: Decent place to work
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: Depending on the program and functional group you're in, there can be very good work/life balance.  In my 5 years here, they have been good not to burn us out.  Pay is good for the area.  Benefits are average for this industry.
cons:
Too much red tape, process, process, process.  Raises and promotions are done by your functional organization (its a matrix org), you can be great on your program work, but if functional doesn't want you to be promoted, etc, then they have the final say.  
While not a Raytheon problem, it is located in Tucson.  It's not a fun city, the roads are awful and its run down.

review_title: Build your skill set, then apply it elsewhere.
pros: The people, pay, and benefits are top-notch.  It is easy to get comfortable there, but after a few years the raises aren't worth it.  I'd say that Raytheon has one of the most stringent supply chain operations in the country and you can build a great skill set to use at another company and get a nice bump in pay elsewhere.  Raytheon recruits quality talent - a must in the industry.
cons: The processes, tools, and audits keep adding to the cycle time of placing orders resulting in a continuously growing backlog.  Resources and replacing workers are hard to get approved resulting in more work, same pay, with the expectation to place orders faster.

review_title: Signing your life away for little pay
pros: If you are someone who cant find a job any where else and you have a passive aggressive mentality that keeps you from standing up for yourself. IF YOU STILL WISH TO WORK HERE AFTER READING THIS I AM SORRY FOR YOU.
cons: where to start......how about everything low pay almost minimum wage, bad leadership, not focused on personal well fare of employees, supervisors pick sides, people legitimitely hate working here and will remind you constantly, low morale, people fall asleep at the job, management is quick to fire you, and did I mention the low pay. All you will ever hear is get your 40 hours but if you add travel back and forth its really close to 50 hours.

review_title: Raytheon
pros: Decent total package (pay, medical, PTO, flex schedule, holidays).  Occasionally you get to work on some cool stuff and make a difference.
cons: Things, even simple things, take way too long to execute.  Too many non-value added tasks and positions.  Much of the work and great things done here are completed by a small percentage of the people.

review_title: A safe but somewhat static place to work.
pros: Good pay and benefits, generally benign management, job security in bad economic times.  Raytheon's HR policies are among the most forward-looking of any company in the defense business.  Opportunities to advance to management are abundant, even if opportunities to advance a technical career are not quite as abundant.  Much of the work force come from the baby-boom generation, and thus will retire soon.  This wave of retirements will clear the way for younger workers to advance their careers.
cons: Process-bound, bureaucratic company, opposite of agile, pays lip service to innovation but R&D performance (where's the money?) is only average for the industry.  In fact, Raytheon IIS's R&D budget is much smaller per employee than other Raytheon business units.

review_title: Sinking ship
pros: Good pay, There is a lot of talent there.
cons: Old boy network,  Constant schedule delays, Put all their eggs in one basket selling too many derivatives based on an initial system.

review_title: Integrated Defense Systems
pros: The engineering community is filled with very smart, engaging individuals.  There is plenty of opportunity to learn and most are willing to share what they know.  The benefits are going to be comparable to what is available with other companies in the area.  Make sure to negotiate a fair salary because if you end up undervalued you won't recover unless you leave the company.
cons: Raytheon tries to adopt the best practices of industry and make them more Raytheon-like.  This often results in additional work for the sake of work in order to make the claim that we've adopted some practice.  Raytheon also does a better job rewarding people who leave the company then come back versus those who are loyal and geniunely interested in making sure Raytheon is the Top Tier Defense Contractor.

review_title: Review from the finance department
pros:
Raytheon have great contractual working hours. (Finish early on Fridays!). Since working here, I have been pushed to take on new opportunities and experiences constantly to improve on my skills and knowledge. Personal development reviews are firmly placed with regular refresh on how I am doing to achieve them. It is clear that there is support available to help achieve them, not only from my team but from wider functions and departments are also willing to assist. (Eg training and mentors are provided) 
In terms of working hard - The functional team have recognised the effort and can sometimes receive rewards, so working hard isn't taken for granted at Raytheon.
cons: Although Raytheon have good contractual hours, most of the time, the work load require you to do a lot more unpaid overtime. - quicker processes are required (eg, IT and softwares issues needs to improve and resolved to increase efficiency)

review_title: Great culture. Could use better lighting
job_title: Systems Engineer IV in Tucson, AZ
pros: Management is always on my side. People treat each other really well. I can feel the importance of what I do. Opportunities to move up are pretty limited but if you prefer to avoid management like I do that's a good thing. Culture is very practical. People actively look for ways to cut out unnecessary work and get the important things done. But if you want to experience a wide variety of disciplines throughout your career, it's a great place because they make it relatively easy to move laterally. Business growth is positive, so I'm not worried about getting laid off in the foreseeable future.
cons: Building I work in is pretty drab. Ugly yellow florescent lighting. I find it slightly depressing.

review_title: Motivation Killer
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros: Excellent salary plus overtime pay and 9/80 flex schedule. Great work available for Computer Science or Electrical Engineering Majors.
cons: Industry average HSA with a high deductible for health coverage, below average 401k match, below average bonus pay, below average merit pay increase, extremely political culture, very hostile environment depending on which department you are hired into, matrix structure is terribly inefficient, no innovative or valuable work for Mechanical Engineers, and not a single model available to develop and define a career path for a collegiate or professional hire. Pursue other companies if you want to make an impact in your career. Raytheon will weaken your skill sets and kill your passion for engineering.

review_title: Improvements needed for this Raytheon location
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Fullerton, CA
pros:
-Flexible in taking PTO whenever you like.
-There are a lot of young engineers to form a nice social group.
cons:
-Ladder and ranking system to determine promotions and merit raises.  Promotions and merit raises are determined in the previous year (ex: For 2009 year, ranking is determined Nov/Dec 2009) before performance reviews/summaries are written and conducted during (ex: For 2009, Feb 2010) for the previous year.  Instead of making everyone's salaries the same, award the top performing employees better raises.
-Expand educational assistance to allow engineers to obtain MBA degrees.  They are the only top 4 aerospace defense contractor to restrict employees to obtain MBA degrees.
-Not much flow down from section managers about job positions in other existing projects within the company in case your current project is ending and phasing out.

review_title: Interesting work, frustrating politics
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II (E04) in Sudbury, MA
pros: Challenging and interesting work. Not all employees are that good, but many are. There are a lot of higher degree (Masters, PhD) holders to learn from. If you are competent, you will have many opportunities. Pay is good, and benefits are competitive.
cons: They overload you with tasks and responsibilities if you are a good worker. Unable to really apply Systems Engineering practices due to customer and managers constantly changing priorities and funding. Not able to make a real plan and follow it, always fighting fires and trying to keep head above water. Until funding gets pulled and there is nothing to do, which is worse. You do not want to be on department overhead. No sick leave. No paternity leave.

review_title: If defense is your passion, and you don't mind stressing out about sensitive information, you'll do great.
pros: Benefits and pay are great. When they say there is mobility (both lateral and upward) in the company, they really mean it. Workplace culture is good.
cons:
Information transfer between outgoing and incoming generations of employees is absolutely terrible and not well regulated. Raytheon is an old company, its workforce is retiring, and its struggling with young employee retention. They'll figure it out, but likely too late. If you want answers to your everyday questions about your tasks, you'll have to work hard to track those answers down.

Working with sensitive information can be an absolute nightmare.

review_title: Great opportunity for proactive, talented young engineers
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer I in El Segundo, CA
pros: Plenty of interesting technical challenges.  Surronded by exceptional senior engineers (Hughes Braintrust). Excellent place to learn.  Rapid retirement creates future opportunitities for young motivated engineers (must be motivated!).  Technical staff is motivated to culture talent.  Many development programs exist.  Company is focused on retaining talent.  Many different locations across US and internationally.  Company has a solid foundation and is poised to be a leader. Stable employement.
cons: Big company makes upward accelleration somewhat restricted.  Some lazy employees are too comfortable and lack motivation. Security clearances can mean most exciting work will be a couple years away for new hires.  Easy to fall into the trap of not working hard as raises are pretty consistent despite performance.

review_title: Strong Values, Meaningful Work
pros: A technology based company, Raytheon products support first responders in emergencies, protect the lives of servicemen and women, facilitate safe travel and other efforts an employee can be proud to have contributed to. The company has multiple sites across the United States, and hires for engineering, manufacturing and multiple functional disciplines. Raytheon promotes core values, and is committed to diversity and inclusion.
cons: The company leans to the conservative, however, this allows Raytheon to perform with consistency. In terms of talent acquisition, requisitions for new hires tend to be written for a siloed approach (for example, to be successful, a candidate must possess X years within the silo; someone with transferrable skills may be "screened out" if their experience comes from another discipline)--not that this is any different than industry peers. Lateral moves for rotational development require a creative approach.

review_title: Finance
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Fullerton, CA
pros: Salary can be decent if you negotiate it well when you hire in.  Management is generally makes well thought out decisions.  We strive to be the business leader in our industry.  The people are generally easy to work with.  We have a wider portfolio of programs than most other defense contractors.
cons: They value time over knowlegde.  A little annoying if you are young.  Fun place to work for the most part.  They will give you as much work or as little as you are able to handle. A couple of fellow young coworkers and I always said 25% of the people in this company do 75% of the work.  The rest are just waiting to retire.

review_title: good salary and benefits, poor, substandard supervisors and managers
pros: they have good pay compared to other companies and the benefits are good as well.  just like any other company doing contract work, you don't know if you have a job around the end of the money year.
cons: leadership, leadership, leadership.  it is the hole in the side of the boat.  they hire ex-officers who have no idea what they are doing and thus bring the entire team down.  the company will hire you for one job and expect you to perform 3 or 4 more jobs on top of that.  These are also jobs that normally have a higher salary too.

review_title: Raytheon
pros: You wok 9/40 which means you have every other friday off and work 9 hours the rest of the days for two weeks.  The pay is good.
cons: They are are not nice people when it comes to laying off and the reorganize all the time.  In 5 years I had 7 different Supervisors.  Training is very mininal and you never know what the right answer is.  they say they want new ideas but if you go against what they have decided is the "best" one.  You are wrong.  Many people are over worked, working weekends and off fridays to keep us since they laid off so many people.

review_title: Good job out of college
pros:
-Once you're in, you're in. It's really hard to get fired here.
-9/80 schedule means you work 9 hour days but get every other Friday off
-Big push for younger engineers and minorities
-Really cool projects to get involved in if you seek them out
cons:
-Creepy old men. If you're a young, pretty, female at this company prepare to possibly cause some cases of whiplash. The best way to counteract that is to hang a picture of your boyfriend in your cube (most guys will get the hint). 
-Soooo many rules and regulations but that comes with the industry
-EXIM sucks. all around sucks.

review_title: Employer of Choice?
pros: Good benefits, flexible hours and working with some great folks. I received good training and the working conditions were generally good.
cons: Many in middle management seemed to be faking it. Educationally, I'm sure they were qualified, but failed miserably in open and honest communications and understanding what their people actually did and why. After 32 years I was laid off within a week of a management change, by my former manager! They understand numbers and think that firing people will fix things.

review_title: Hiring and promotions
pros: Raytheon Missile Systems is a decent place to work if already solidified at mid level career. Decent benefits for Tucson in general.
cons: Hiring practices are ruining this as a desirable job. HR openly admits that they will not allow an employee to hire internally into another job that is above 1 promotional step above their current position regardless of qualifications. They will even vote the company policy on this. If an employee quits and then applies externally they stand a chance at that position but not from within. This has lead to much turn over of qualified and experienced talent leaving the company to seek employment with competitors.

review_title: Flexible work. Attempting to retain talent
pros: Easy to take days off when needed.  Well-establishes programs. Job security. Workcan be easy or challenging depending on your drive. Opportunities for career advancement if in right position and timing. Many senior engineers willing to mentor. Management supports changing jobs internally to find passion
cons: Takes awhile to move up in ranking. Difficult to obtain above average raises at beginning of career. Easy to get stuck in a position that is monotonous. A lot of managers and manager shuffling for whatever reason.  Great disconnect between “higher ups”and junior engineers. Departments very independent.

review_title: Great customer to support!
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Springfield, VA
pros: The customer you are supporting makes your work very rewarding. You know that you are impacting the lives of your customer each day.  The work environment was very friendly and each person was easy to get along with.  The team I was on held fun outings every few months. The management team I was under communicated very well with us and let us know how we could improve and rewarded us when we went the extra mile.  The people were very willing to show you new things and help you learn new areas of the system. Teamwork was very important in the group I was a part of.
cons: The location I was at and the specific program I was on did not have many opportunities for advancement.  I had to look outside my immediate program.

review_title: A good place to start.
pros:
work/life balance, casual dress code that is highly conducive to a productive environment.  I've seen much smaller, lesser companies make a big issue out of a dress code and drive employees crazy when they don't even have to meet customers in person.  People can do a lot more when they are comfortable.
I thought the benefits were decent and I thought the people were very friendly and professional.
cons: I don't know the company well enough at this point to critique it.

review_title: Look out, Watch out, or Step out.
job_title: Production Control Planner in Andover, MA
pros: The quality of the people who work  there to earn a living. They are more down to earth and willing to help you out in a pinch. Also the work can be rather challanging at times ( if you get assigned to the right programs).
cons: Nepotism, favoritism and worst of all, the ass kissers. Very tough to avoid. It stiffles growth and creates lots of tension within departments. Hard to work around and puts a tremenous burden on the real quality people. Everyone knows who they are and how they got to be where they are today. Just a very large company that has grown way to big for its own good.

review_title: Good benefits but tense environment
job_title: Software Engineer I in Brea, CA
pros:
- Decent salary.
- Good benefits package, where it offers many choices for medical healthcare plans, and vision & dental are included.  There's also a 401K plan.
- Fair amount of PTO and paid holidays.
- Younger crowd is fun and great to work with.
- Large amount of diversity promotion and various events to make things more enjoyable at work.
cons:
- Too much pressure at work. Can be stressful most of the time.
- Expectations from management are often times unreasonable.
- Not much training for newer people.
- Not much respect from senior employees toward younger ones.
- Many unreasonable idiosyncrasies such as having to work overtime without getting overtime paid unless coming in on the weekends.
- Working with outdated technology that are not useful anywhere else.

review_title: Good Company with Serious Problems
pros: Great pay, benefits, large company with opportunity to move around, better opportunity than elsewhere in town, wonderful smart employees in difficult technical fields, you can stay here career long if you want
cons: No concern for work-life balance, doesn't value the information capital in people with long careers, no knowledge management policy, doesn't value truth in speech, values the short term over the long term, speaks the innovation speak but doesn't follow through with actual R&D funding, funding for projects is difficult and bureaucratic and seemingly not tied to performance, doesn't really want to know if employees are happy . . . would rather wring them out and them prop them up with money

review_title: Bloated, bureaucratic, but pays well in a good location.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer I in El Segundo, CA
pros:
Usually not stressful. Unlike other comercial companies (not in the defense sector) you won't find too many people working lots of overtime. Partly because nobody has the drive or the interesting projects that draw them in on the weekend. Mostly though, it is because Raytheon is like any other Government contractor (especially defense contractors) - there is little incentive because the more hours the project takes, the more we get to charge the government.

The El Segundo location is a great location in the Southbay. Raytheon compensation seems pretty competitive.
cons: Bureaucratic and slow about everything - means you learn and progress less.  Secrecy is a part of almost every project and is a huge pain in the ass to deal with from an engineering perspective.

review_title: Middle of the pack defense contractor
pros: It pays well.  Position is relatively stable.  You get to work some interesting, cutting edge technology some of the time.  For me the commute distance is the most attractive feature.  I live about 9 miles away from the job and am able to get to work in less than 20-25 minutes most of the time.
cons: Benefits are bad.  Work environment is bad.  Employee morale is really bad.  Most of the employees are dissatisfied by the work environment.  Not much support from the senior management, human resource department etc..  Most of the employees don't feel respected.  It is a hire and fire company; you see layoffs all the time in other groups.   It hasn't affected us yet.

review_title: New Hire :|
job_title: Software Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: The location is great.  Near the beach, near LAX, near freeway and public transport. As with any large aerospace company, you get decent health benefits, competitive pay, and employee networking groups.  Work schedule is quite flexible with the option to work a 9/80.
cons: In my department, it seems management are too busy to deal with new hires' problems.  Unlike other aerospace companies, they don't give you anything to do (constructive or not) while waiting on security clearances.  Which can take weeks to months.  Other companies will usually find tasks that don't require clearance.  Not as social an enviornment as I was expecting. Medium to low morale all around.  As with any aerospace company, you are expected to work maybe 50-60 hrs/wk.  Pay lower than I expected for aerospace industry.

review_title: It's easy to get lost in the shuffle.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in Woburn, MA
pros:
If you aren't very motivated and you're a low achiever, you'll get lost in the shuffle here.  Nobody will fire you.  You'll just get moved around from project to project as you upset your co-workers.  
Lots of projects to choose from.
cons: You don't always know how to move from project to project.  Easy to get pigeon-holed.  Every department has vastly different budgets for raises and promotions.  Therefore, equal treatment for equal work isn't usually the case between departments.

review_title: It's easy to get lost in the shuffle.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in Boulder, CO
pros:
If you aren't very motivated and you're a low achiever, you'll get lost in the shuffle here.  Nobody will fire you.  You'll just get moved around from project to project as you upset your co-workers.  
Lots of projects to choose from.
cons: You don't always know how to move from project to project.  Easy to get pigeon-holed.  Every department has vastly different budgets for raises and promotions.  Therefore, equal treatment for equal work isn't usually the case between departments.

review_title: You Are Just a Number
pros: Interesting projects, products, and a lot of nice people at the working level.
cons: Employees are treated as commodities. I was laid off 2 weeks ago. After being told on a Monday morning I had 2 hours to clean out my office and turn in my badge. I had a lot of work on my project and was being asked to work overtime. The program manager could not believe I was being laid off. There was no plan for anyone to pick up and cover my work. It was a complete screw up. My section manager was calling me the week after my layoff asking me how to find the data files I was working on.

review_title: Very good big 5 company
pros: Raytheon is a great company to work at.  There are a lot of opportunities to grow your career and interact with some of the leading experts in the defense industry.  The leadership is very interested in promoting from within and nurturing their talent to become effective leaders.
cons: Raytheon does have some the draw backs of big aerospace businesses.  It can be processes laden which can make it slower and less responsive to its customer needs.  The middle managers   can be a 50/50 draw, they are either really great managers who measure their success by the success of their direct reports, or they are occupying a desk solely.  I have worked for and with both types.

review_title: New CEO has ruined the previously great company
pros: good benefits and 9/80 work week
cons: new management now cares way more about the companies margins than its employees. So corners are cut across the board.  It amazing for a rich company to be so cheap. From eliminating any spending on employees training and food or even coffee expenses, to not having any  Christmas Holiday celebrations (none at all, not even a pot luck lunch) to actual layoffs (that's despite company  having record profits). The company is now operating as a cheap sweat shop

review_title: Focused much more on process than engineering
job_title: Electrical Engineer I in Andover, MA
pros: Every other Friday off.  Some of the people that work their are very friendly.
cons: Conflicting views from different areas of management.  Upper level management says that your can get in trouble for working and then not charging it but a lot of project leads try to pressure you into not charging hours after doing work for them.  Also hard to receive help as no one wants to help if they are afraid they won't receive a contract to charge.  When starting at the company there is no reasoning behind where they put you.  Also management in your section gets upset if you do not do a Six Sigma project but its almost impossible to find funding for a project in some areas.

review_title: Great company!
job_title: Scrum Master/Senior Software Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: Great benefits!
cons: Contract ended

review_title: Easily the worst company I've worked for
pros: Good work/life balance, benefits and retirement plans
cons: Raytheon is a very profit-driven company and does not care about its employees. Every echelon of my management save for my direct supervisor has shown no regard or interest in my welfare in or outside of the company. They will compensate you initially for extra hours worked and then find some technicality to take it away so your time is unpaid. Management is never on the same page and issues contradicting information. Management is also very out of touch with the actual services we provide to the customer, resulting in contradicting direction from Raytheon and customer management.

review_title: Raytheon: a great place for moms to work
pros: Raytheon offers very good benefits, such as part-time and flexible schedules. Can take up to a year leave of absence without pay and return to a job at same salary and seniority.  They are working hard to promote diversity.
cons: Managers are not necessarily trained to lead before they are given a leadership role.  This means that they are not always good with people.  There is a strong focus on corporate culture, which sometimes distracts from being effective at work.  Also, we spend a lot of time training about safety considering that software engineers spend most of their day sitting at a desk.

review_title: Some potential, but if you're a contractor, not so much
pros: It's a huge company - 70,000 plus people - with locations all over the world. If you're willing to work hard, there is potential to be promoted. You usually will put in long hours, but you have flexibility to come in later and work from home. Salaries are comparable or better to other defense contractors, and you are eligible for benefits on the first day of employment.
cons: Management is clueless and unprofessional - there is one manager who NEVER forgets anything and takes things way too personally and "punishes" people as she sees fit. HR does not have a reputation of being very effective when listening to employee complaints. As with most large corporations, the rank and file employees do all the work and management pretty much coasts.

review_title: Old school with lots of office politics
pros: Raytheon offers generous compensation packages.Good salaries and benefits however benefits are starting to slip.  Medical plans have become weak with poor coverage.
cons: Hard to accomplish things here with too much bureaucracy and office politics.  It is often not what you know but who you know in order to be recognized.  Not a friendly culture with little regard to its employees.  Poor leadership that is more interested with ticking off the boxes than actually doing anything meaningful.  Inflexible and unable to keep up with more modern business practices.

review_title: A great company but driven by bean-counters, micro-managers, and over-reacting to burning platform mentality.
job_title: Engineering Support Tech in El Segundo, CA
pros: Great benefits.  Stable work environement.  Recognition and advancement.
cons: You have to be extremely self-driven to get ahead but don't ever step on any toes.  Over the last 5 years legacy systems that were the bread and butter of success have been replaced by new software driven control systems that have put handcuffs on how processes are done.  Bean counters rule the programs and R&D is barely negligable.  We lose valuable projects to outside vendors because we have initiated stringent new policies on ourselves that make us more expensive than outside work.  There are too many chiefs and not enough indians anymore.

review_title: Good workplace!
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: There are many capable and well educated associates, with good experience in the products developed and manufactured at my location.  There is good teamwork and cordiality at a working level.  Management generally is supportive of good work, and gives commendations when important successful milestones are reached.  There is opportunity for innovation at my location, and the company is generally supportive of patents that recognize innovation.
cons: Most projects seem underbid in time and schedule, so there are pressures to work unpaid overtime.  Management at the Santa Barbara site is remotely located in El Segundo, and comes from a different "culture" that is appearance oriented, where our site is results oriented.  This remote management also is very demanding of procedural reports, which slow down the work that needs to be done.

review_title: Systems Engineer. Long days, slow work, but you learn a lot.
pros: Ability to choose work or projects that interest you, inside or outside of your section. Flexible schedule, as long as you are there from 9am-3pm. Every other Friday off is really nice as well.
cons: Office locations are south of town, so basically wherever you live it will be a commute. No shaded parking which is terrible in AZ. Not a lot of employee benefits. Raises, promotions, and awards are hard to come by. Work/life balance isn’t great. Dominated by those that served in the military, so if you didn’t, be prepared to feel lost in a lot of conversations. Work can be slow, sometimes projects take much longer than they should.

review_title: Talk to a current employee you trust before taking a job at this Raytheon location...
pros: Solid benefits package, pride in supporting our Nation's military. Raytheon has a good reputation in the Defense industry as an employer. Some benefits of working for larger Raytheon business units trickle down to smaller locations such as Indianapolis. Work life balance is very good.
cons: Highly political environment, top heavy management structure means little chance for advancement. Job descriptions provided during hiring process are grossly exaggerated in terms of responsibility and challenge offered. I was lied to about crucial career decisions and opportunities several times during my time at RTSC Indy. Leadership there will tell you anything to get you on board, but once you are there it is a different story - must be the bait and switch capital of the corporation. I kept expecting to bump into The Smoking Man at any moment and have him remind me to "trust no one..."

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros: Interesting work that contributes to the country. Good at trying in the purpose of current tasking to end goals. Answering the question of 'Why does this matter' or 'Why does my job matter'. Great advancement oportunities and potential. If you are a hard worker and quick at learning new stuff - you can do well.  Less politics than many other places. Good at conducting and supporting training oportunities. Offer dozens of technical classes to expand your skill set. Feed back on performance. Great people to work with.
cons: Large company with bueracracy, though less than many others. Lots of work - it will take over your life if you let it.

review_title: Good technology company, needs to modernize its management approaches
job_title: Program Manager in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Part of the defense/aerospace industry, helping to protect our nation.  Lots of great technology to work on,  lots of great people to work with.  Uses mature  & well-defined processes & procedures.  Has numerous nationwide / worldwide locations, and there are opportunities to relocate / move around the country and/or world.
cons: Outdated management practices (think northeast corporate culture from the '60s / '70s).  The company uses an employee performance review system similar to Microsoft's "stacking" review system.  Recent significant reorganizations, loss of local leadership (without being replaced), and layoffs have been causing chaos and degraded morale among the employees.

review_title: Negative
pros: They have had longevity as a company till now, salary and benefits are good.  There is no indication of discrimination.
cons: Work space built for keeping eye on employees--dehumanizing lack of privacy, in fact, dehumanizing in general.  Concern seems to be ultimately with form, not function--politics.  Research and development there is essentially dead--the company's future seems to depend upon shrewd lobbying with Washington.  Worked for (legacy-Hughes) Raytheon about a decade before, things have gone far downhill in my view.  I was warned about these realities by a former supervisor before hiring in--but I couldn't afford to heed his advice, as I needed the work for as long as it lasted.

review_title: Varied Career opportunities and experience, excellent benefits, but you're at the mercy of local management.
pros: Great pay, great experience, great benefits, and good (if sporadic) opportunities. The technological challenges and projects are interesting and rewarding.
cons: The whole business seems to be in such a state of flux, that you don't know what you'll be doing from one year to the next. Also, your quality of work life can vary dramatically from one location or project to another. On one project you'll feel like you have management support, you'll work mostly 40 hours a week, and people get along. On another project, you'll work 60 hours a week, you'll constantly dread a conversation or request for status from your manager, and everyone constantly talks about how bad it is.

review_title: Workforce is self serving and cliquey and is agressive/passive toward management.
pros: The opportunities apear to be challenging.  The Benefits are consistent with industry norms.  The hiring package is generous.  Seem to have a genuine concern for the health and wellfare of there employees.
cons: The workforce consists of an amalgamation of companies that have been relocated to Tucson.  These cultures are incompatible and are covertly at odds.  New hires are singled out and have their efforts sabotaged.  If you are talented and a fast learner, your talents will not be nurtured and you will be held back with inferior assignments.  Middle management operates under their own set of values which do not support upper management.  The people who have created a perception of success by being expedient have gained powerful middle management positions and invoke a coercive management style to maintain their position.  This results in a negatively manipulative environment.

review_title: Happy for now
job_title: Software Engineer I in Plano, TX
pros: Stimulating work, relaxed atmosphere (business casual), great co-workers.  Getting time-off when needed for emergencies, or just last minute plans is pretty easy, because of the size of the company.  Many opportunities for advancement.  Yearly reviews and raises are pretty consistent.  You definitely know what the career path is; the company goes to great lengths to make sure that all employees know what's expected of them.  For the most part, Raytheon, as a company abides by it's core values and stated objectives.  The work pace is reasonable for someone who loves what they do and is motivated.  If you don't like what you do, I would imagine that it could be a pretty tough place to work.
cons: Very large company, so sometimes you can feel like a very small and insignificant cog in a very large machine.

review_title: Maybe a good place for an engineer, look elsewhere for other positions
pros: Good opportunities to move around the company, between locations and even job functions. I always found my interactions with employees to be friendly, there are not a lot of big egos here and there is a good sense of teamwork. If you make the effort, you can develop an excellent network, even including members of the executive team.
cons: Raytheon reflects the mentality of most of its government customers, often slow to change and bureaucratic. Not the most efficient on the business management and finance side, though I can't speak for engineering. Financial systems here are outdated and there is a lot of manual work that could be automated. Like many corporate finance jobs, the work is cyclical and can become boring.

review_title: A great place to start out
pros: Great benefits including many health insurance options, vision, dental, short/long term disability.  I am fotunate to work with a lot of younger employees who make the work environment a fun place to come to every day. The 9/80 workweek which is an option at most facilities is great, having every other Friday off is the best! They will also pay for graduate courses.
cons: I've been working at Raytheon for over a year now and not once have I received a "good job" or any type of acheivement award. The first year is all about completing your six sigma project which many departments don't take too seriously. Doesn't seem easy to get promoted but there are plenty of internal jobs to tranfer to all around the country/world.

review_title: It's a bad time to apply for Raytheon
pros:
pretty "decent" pay especially if you are single.  
depending on where you work, it's heaven, hell, or somewhere in between.
respect isn't given so I guess you don't have to respect others.  so I guess that's a pro.  :)
cons: this company values people with the ability to get a high clearance than the actual technical merits / education of the employees.  I have seen time to time where new hires who really actually know nothing (and this isn't really a joke) get paid as much as people who have served with this company for 5-10 years with TONS of experience more than the new hire.  Even tons of experience when the veterans came to apply as a new hire.

review_title: Pursue if you like the comfort of functional specialization and relationship based advancement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Incredibly smart talent pool; interesting and cutting edge technology; competitive pay and benefits; well-intentioned lower level leaders
cons: Fear-based, risk averse culture; lack of accountability or consequences for not meeting performance expectations; activity not results based environment; fire drill and reactive based; command and control, bureaucratic; silos based not systemic or process; lack of transparency, vision or focus

review_title: Decent Company to work for
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Recognize talent and willing to help employee continue to develop their career. Great work life balance. Will pay for 1x OT whenever OT is needed. Most .com doesn't pay for OT but work 60 hours a week.
cons: Some managers use their position as stepping stone and don't watch for the best interest of people under them. Upper manager doesn't realize or maybe not willing to admit that a lot of people take the section manager route just to get their promotion without proofing themselves. Everyone is aware of this which is such for engineer who really contribute to the success of the company.

review_title: Raytheon SAS
job_title: Project Manager/Facilities Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Competitive salary and good benefits. Regular raises with decent performance reviews..They encourage training and continuing education (will pay in some cases). Seem to be serious about diversity (from what I saw). I am a little biased, because I liked the small group of people that I worked with more than usual.
cons: It is a very large Company with large campuses. Sometimes a little too large. Unwieldy at times.  I was laid off because the SAS division lost a contract. Aerospace is a bit too cutthroat at times.

review_title: Good Company
pros: Have been able to move between functions to grow skills and career. Great benefits and PTO offered. Can work from home as needed and set own work schedule. Has formal mentor program, but have found selecting my own mentors in a non-formal sense to be more effective. Focuses on diversity and inclusion; great culture
cons: Career growth and advancement is dependent upon division and group you support; cut profit sharing and increased achievement awards - though rarely given.

review_title: Marketing Manager
job_title: International Marketing Manager in Waterloo, ON
pros: Raytheon has a vast selection of product offerings and strives to operate at the highest levels of ethical/commercial compliance.  Salaries are at competitive levels as well as benefits.  My experience has been that there are many opportunities for advancement  and staff are encouraged to move across roles/disciplines when one exhibits interest and ability.
cons: As with most corporate organizations, decision making is very distributed across a complex management structure leading to very slow changes in business approaches.  This company is well suited to executing large government programs as opposed to working in the commercial domain  which requires a more competitive and agile approach.

review_title: Great place to work if you are looking for a comfortable job
job_title: Program Control Analyst in Falls Church, VA
pros: Raytheon is a great place to work if you have a family and you really need work/life balance. Its a great place if you enjoy being comfortable with your job and you are somewhat interested in career growth. The people at Raytheon are very nice and helpful. They also have great benefits.
cons: Raytheon is average at best in compensation and raises. There are no guidelines in terms how you can grow to the next position. If you feel that you should be up for promotion, nothing will be done unless you push to initiate the process.

review_title: The People Make the Place!!! Compensation is Ehhh...
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The people that you interact with daily make the environment awesome.  If you are working on the design side of things and have a great team your ideas may be implemented.  The people make the place.  Most of the interesting programs are in the northeast area.
cons: We are currently merging the working environment so it is becoming more and more difficult to do get things done.  Every defensive contractor has the issue with documentation and red tape but its becoming more and more of a hassle.

review_title: Cnc Machinist
pros: Nice clean place to work, decent pay and lots of nice benefits. Profit sharing and movie tickets on your birthday. Lots of overtime. Overall a fairly good place to work.
cons:
A few good people but most of the people were miserable and always playing childish games with each other. The production manager was clueless and had very little respect for his department even though they were all tradesmen. A lot of backstabbing if you were a hard worker.
Too many employees that didn't care about their jobs and the good employees had to take up the slack.

review_title: Awesome work, significant red tape
pros:
-There are plenty of opportunities to move around
-Employees resource groups are a great way to get involved and get face time with upper management 
-Get to work on state of the art technology that makes a difference
cons:
-Pay raises are very small
-Red tape keeps deserving people from getting promotions and instead people who are “due” get them
-Engineers who are not in the engineering organization are treated as second class

review_title: Would recommend if you live in the area lots of challenging work.
job_title: Senior Multi-Disciplined Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Diversity of projects to work on due to the high number of contracts at the El Segundo location.  Good benefits and relatively relaxed atmosphere.  I rated my experience rather high because I worked on well funded challenging contracts that gave the opportunity for travel and overtime if wanted, not mandatory.  However, I know people that worked on contracts with funding problems and they seemed to dread their job.  I can only grade Raytheon based on my particular work experience.
cons: Location, painful commute.  There are not many desireable, affordable housing areas near El Segundo and there is no easy way through the traffic.  Many facilities look 30 years old.

review_title: A combination of the good and the bad.
pros:
Raytheon is a very well regarded within the defense industry.

A good choice of benefits is available for employees to enroll (e.g., health, dental, vision, life, disability, flexible spending account, and 401k).

The facilities are very nice and modern.

The office is fairly small so you will get to know almost everyone.

Management recognizes successful employees with merit bonuses.

Opportunities to transfer to other locations.

Focus on continuous process improvement with employees' input.
cons:
Vacation time and sick time are in the same pool.  Not much vacation time can be banked.

Roth 401k is not available.

More employees are needed to spread out the workload, but an excessive focus on profits prevents additional hiring.  Lots of unpaid overtime is required.  It is very difficult to take time off because of the workload.

review_title: Lots of opportunities, need a strong network
job_title: Supply Chain Specialist I in Andover, MA
pros: Good benefits, large company with ample opportunities and locations, good pay overall (it is my understanding that the defense industry pays well, Raytheon is no exception)
cons: A lot of red tape.  Getting "things done" is a challenge due to the many  established processes.  Depending where you are, knowing who the right person to talk to is critical at times - easier said than done.  Good network is important in order to move up.   Very difficult to stick out if you are a good performer.

review_title: Not the best 'foot in the door'
pros: Relaxed work environment, some interesting work
cons: The company likes to say you have career flexibility and you should take charge of your own destiny, except that cannot be further from the truth. If you are a new grad that's looking to get your foot in the door and take ANY engineering job thinking you might be able to move around...don't come here. If you were like me and took the position so you could get an opportunity to do something you actually like, you will feel lied to. I have been trying to move to a field I like from one I am merely functional at. I do good work in my 'functional' field but would be much more productive in my preferred field, yet the company WILL NOT let me apply for postings within my skill level because they are ONLY for people without post college work experience.

review_title: Raytheon is a good place to work.
pros:
What we do directly affects the warfighter.  The company has good benefits and has multiple programs to support the employees.  There are ample opportunities for continuing education.  The OneRTN philosophy has opened up the different divisions to information sharing.
In addition to company holidays, I get  200 hrs (4 weeks) vacation tiem.
cons: Women do not get equal treatment, though the company policies strive to support equality in the workplace.  Many are directed into positions that tend to "pigeon hole' them in areas with little recognition or potential for advancement.

review_title: Systems Engineer
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Fullerton, CA
pros: Very flexible schedule even with the 980 schedule. Mediocre benefits. 10k a year for tuition reimbursement. Year end government shutdown. It's a great place to work if you are older and have a family, since you put in your hours and leave at the same time everyday.
cons: Not a place I would recommend if you are still very early in your career. Lots of red tape. No clear vision. No transparency. Leadership is pretty weak. Not a whole lot of direction from management. Lots of silos. Weak incentives and bonuses equate to low motivation to do well. Slow and weak organizational culture. Difficult to move up, as you get stuck doing one thing. Pretty easy to fall between the organizational cracks. Projects aren't that exciting and technology is archaic. Mentorship program is pretty weak. No leadership development program. No real loyalty from employees.

review_title: Great company for tech folks
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: The best reasons to work at Raytheon is that they are fully involved in cutting edge technologies and they offer many locations across the United States as well as International locations.  They treat you like a professional.  If you are technical, you can stay technical; you do not have to go into Management in order to progress in your career.
cons: Some of the downsides of working at Raytheon are that the available of jobs goes up or down depending upon the economy.  When it comes time for reduction in force, sometimes the more seasoned individuals may get caught up in a layoff because at lean times, only extremely "value added" positions are "safe".

review_title: Hard work is the reward for hard work.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Tewksbury, MA
pros: If you enjoy working for the US government and working within large organizations Raytheon is the place for you.  They give a lot of employee flexibility with time off and treat employees with respect.  The work is constantly changing and there are lots of programs to work on located across the country.
cons: Very little innovation is encouraged within government programs for Defense.  Which can stifle some employees.  The company is also heavily populated by older entrenched co-workers and management which can completely stop any growth and change.

review_title: So far so good.....
job_title: Electrical Engineer II in Tucson, AZ
pros: Raytheon has interesting work and many things you can be involved with just by transferring to different businesses.  You do not have to go to another company to work on something different.  Right now there are plenty opportunities and variety as far as work goes.  I feel the pay the benefits or good, but I am not sure how it compares with other companies.  I know out of school, for the location, they offered the best.
cons: Not enough motivation to have success other than not working weekends and no good way to bring on new ideas.  I believe since all of the programs are military, new ideas seem to be looked down upon.  Things ideas recieved, still be not be implemented.

review_title: A large company that had many opportunities world wide if you are flexible to meet their needs
pros: competitive pay that might not be as high as some others but the ability for management to progress your career is as good as I have ever seen. They also would provide regular gifts that make you feel more appreciated than most other companies.
cons: the benefits arent as good as I would have thought from such a large company but they may be a result from Obama's medical bill that was recently passed I heard it used to be better.

review_title: Experience will vary greatly depending on what project you are assigned.
pros: Good smart people all around, friendly and always willing to help you with questions.  Good benefits.  Flexible schedule.
cons:
Very unreasonable schedules.  Estimates made at the beginning of a project before full scope is known are then taken as gospel and written in stone even after new information is uncovered.  

Employees frequently work on multiple tasks, but the multi-tasking needed is taken to the extreme.  

Low morale, seems like no one is happy to be there.

review_title: Challenging times ahead - good company for younger employees
job_title: Financial Analyst in El Segundo, CA
pros: Good benefits although they are shrinking just like all the other larger defense cos. Career advancement: If you are young and ambitious, there are good programs to develop you and you will be assigned a mentor.
cons: Experience not valued as much as youth, part of the cost cutting strategy is to get rid of older employees in some states and moving functions out to lower cost, less regulated states. Everything being equal and with both employees starting in the company at the same time, the younger employee is set up for success whereas the older employee is not given the same opportunity for training, support and advancement.

review_title: Work with great people on interesting problems, but with last year's technology
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Aurora, CO
pros: The company has a great mission-focus. Coworkers are competent and resourceful. There's an emphasis on respect in the workplace that means we can all work together on the mission. There are a lot of interesting problems they're trying to solve, and opportunities across the US and around the globe.
cons: Working within the defense contractor award/fulfill cycle, we always seem to be a few years behind in technology. A lot of the jobs are in Washington, DC, California, and Texas, which are locations that don't appeal to everyone, whether due to cost, commute time, or culture.

review_title: Look elsewhere if you can
pros: Good, talented people are always leaving.  If you aren't a horrible employee, you won't ever get laid off--they have a continuous need for fresh meat to feed the grinder.   Simply by attrition of the better employees, you will have opportunity to move up in the company.
