cons: From my point of view management does not care about the employees anymore. Even when you're happy where you are there's no guarantee that you'll remain there. You can get yanked out and sent to another project that needs people or is somehow not living up to expectations.

review_title: Post, Post employment
job_title: Project Manager in El Segundo, CA
pros: A extremely wide variety of product types, customers, technologies and options to develop one's career if you are willing to make it happen.
cons: Languishing product lines are allowed to slowly die.  Good people are wasted.

review_title: Great Company, Stable and Growing
job_title: Supply Chain Specialist I in Tucson, AZ
pros: Raytheon is a great company that has been defending the U.S. for decades. If you want a career that gives you the stability of a government job but pays the salary of a professional position, this is the place to work.
cons: As with all large corporations, bureaucracy slows all decision making down and makes Raytheon slow to react. Also, security is a big deal, and there are downsides to working with the government.

review_title: Great company!
pros: Ethical leadership, great advancement opportunities, and diversified portfolio of projects/products.  The range of products is very broad and allows each individual the opportunity to work production, development, and IRADs.
cons: IRAD is very strategic and the days of working fundamental research or extremely low TRL products is left to university partners or National Labs.  Much training and process is flowed from the top down with little notice and no consultation with stakeholders who must implement changes.

review_title: An exceptional company
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Invested greatly in training engineers a program management. Very disciplined with making key decisions with data versus emotions or politics. Very good benefits and pay.
cons: Getting too politically correct about social issues where it seemed the management was forcing down employees' throats. One senior manager claimed the site was filled with nothing but bigots. Seemed extreme considering programs had exceptional teams doing great work. Promotional opportunities seemed slow or not existent.

review_title: Great career
pros: I like the wide variety of jobs I have been able to do without having to relocate across the US.  They have a wide variety of development programs for high performers.  Raises are based on performance versus spread fairly evenly across everyone.
cons: With the current budget outlook and uncertainty, it is going to be a challenging next few years.  More and more is expected on your own time to control overhead.

review_title: Antiquated in a lot of ways
job_title: Financial Analyst II in Andover, MA
pros:
Very flexible hours and schedule
Depending on the groups, very good a fostering young talent
Great Heathcare Benefits
cons: Benefits and salary are based on the 'pension' model. If you're lucky enough to have made the deadline before they only offered 401k matching it's amazing. A hire to retire company. Having missed that date, I believe the cut of was 2009, it's tough to justify staying at the salaries they offer.

review_title: Good Company. Good Benefits. Good People.
pros: The benefits at  Raytheon are good. Most  people who work for Raytheon are good people. The possess strong support of the military and those in the military.
cons: Raytheon use to be an employer of choice. However in present  years the company treats their employees more like numbers.  They have lost their human factor.  If you plan on retiring there you won't. They lay off people with tenure before you have a chance to retire.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: Work-week can be hectic, but overall the experience has been great. Work/life balance is great and they offer a really great benefits program.
cons: Working on contracts often means there is little room for innovation, many parts of the contract have been moved out from in-house to remote or offshore locations to bring down costs.

review_title: Engineer
pros: Strong presence in the defense industries. Many offices in the States and abroad. Gives new hires ample amount of time to catch up to speed. Many travel opportunities if you have the desirable skillset.
cons: Due to the nature of contractual work, a good portion of the workforce does EXACTLY 8hr days. Big corporation means one must make friends in the management team if one is determined to climb the corporate ladder

review_title: Almost a winner!!
pros:
Liberal Work From Home Policy
Good Benefit Package
Pension (managed to get in early before it shutdown)
Good 401K match
Yearly raises and bonuses
cons:
Red Tape & Bureaucracy
Slow growth/promotions - especially for minorities (received >5 "exceeds requirements" in the past consecutive years which equals a better raise but in most other companies that would equate to a promotion)

review_title: Software Engineer
pros:
1) Relaxed environment
2) Work hour flexibility
cons:
1) Poor management and bureacracy
2) Bad culture - endorses slackers rather than the hard working
3) Slow career growth - If you want your career to be on the fast-track, then I don't recommend this company 
4) outdated technology
5) Convoluted requirements - Please make sure you have the requirements down and pat before issuing work to the engineers. I found myself spending half my time trying to find someone who actually understands the requirements, and the other half of my time working.
6) Don't really care about employees - they will ignore all the good work you've done, and focus exclusively on the mistakes you've made.

review_title: Program manager
pros: Get to work with the top engineers and scientists in defense. Learn innovative material. Great place to start a career. It pays well.
cons: After 3 years many peoples careers stagnate. The pay is good which often leads to becoming a prisoner to your income. Job security doesn't exist. When large programs end, you could end up being forced out. Ethics are very grey.

review_title: Raytheon Pros and Cons
pros: Working at Raytheon is great. They are very flexible with your work schedule and there are many opportunities within the Raytheon company.
cons: The biggest con about working at Raytheon is the lack of recognition for some of the employees working at Raytheon.

review_title: Excellent Company with tremendous compensation benefits
pros: The work performed at Raytheon is world-class, innovative, and, in most cases, industry leading.  The compensation package is far ahead of the industry
cons: As with all large companies, the ability to rapidly respond to disruptive technologies is slow which often leads to applying existing technologies to address new, emerging opportunities

review_title: Meaningful mission and exciting technology
pros: It’s not hard to excel if you’re smart, the company does some really cool things with technology and national security, and work-life balance is generally great
cons: Very bureaucratic, with outdated processes. Not enough of a meritocracy, where years experience determine your salary more than the actual value you add.

review_title: Good Company and People
pros: The company has good people who have a mix of talent and promotes diversity and great work life balance.  Very good training programs and for the most part everyone is well compensated.
cons: If you are young, (depending on the department) might not be aggresive enough towards your career and professional growth.  Again, depends on the department and management's recognition or room for growth that may turn you off.

review_title: Great company and perfect place to start a career.
job_title: Financial Analyst II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Raytheon is a great place to develop strong forecasting and communication skills. Other benefits include - world-wide locations, 9/80 schedules, and great health/work life benefits.
cons: Career advancement is not always balanced and is generally focused on years of experience versus talent. Job resposibilities are not always defined and high turnover coupled with staffing issues linger.

review_title: Great Place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Dallas, TX
pros: Direct management (i.e. the folks I really work for) is excellent.   Pay is competitive, and work/life balance is excellent.  The flexible work schedule, when workload allows, is very beneficial.   My experience has been that the company works hard to place employees between contracts.
cons: It can be stressful when the project you're working on ends, depending on what new contracts are being awarded.  Emphasis on Six Sigma is annoying.  Benefits are not what they were when I first joined the company.

review_title: not sure what this field is
pros: Great benefits and understanding management, various opportunities available for advancement, locations all over the world, provides assistance for higher education, various assistance programs
cons: Vacation time not sufficient for mothers with young children, not enough family support programs, there aren't any social functions where the employees can bring their family to meet other employees and their families

review_title: Second review.. After 3 years at Raytheon.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
* 9/80 Work Schedule
* Flexible work schedule
* Project crunch times usually followed by a week or two of slow-down
* Friendly employees
* Management does an excellent job with creating a fun work-site
* Most senior management is very easy to approach and seem very human
* Seniority isn't something that is constantly rubbed in your face
cons:
* Moving from program to program can be difficult. The ramp up time for programs is atrocious. You can literally spend a month trying to become fairly competent and useful on a program. The programs really need to try to put together a resource package (e.g a wiki) for new transfers.
* Work load is feast-or-famine. At times you will be completely slammed and asked to work overtime and then the following week you'll be twiddling your thumbs while your lead tries to find something for you to do. Of course you then get a guilt trip for not being productive.
* Some programs have a severe resource bottleneck that can lead into situations where you have to work night shifts. This is a bit ridiculous since salaried employees do not get a shift differential and there is absolutely no acknowledgement or appreciation when an employee has to work the 6:00pm-2:00am shift. I don't see how this can be expected.
* "Just get it done" mentality. Leads and managers who are constantly worrying about program performance tend to underbid the difficulty of tasks then are quick to throw engineers under the bus when they are unable to finish a task on budget. (e.g they tell their managers that they tried to meet budget then blame the engineers when the budget is blown or the schedule is slipped).

review_title: Slow and steady
pros: I would say the pay was reasonable and the work atmosphere is pretty casual. I have made a lot of friends here and at the least the non-management employees are really eager to help you out.
cons: It is a big company where the top guys fly themselves on private corporate jets and rarely interact with the lowly engineers.

review_title: Good Place to start your professional career.
job_title: Senior Electronics Technician in Juana Diaz, PR
pros: Very good company, while I have only worked at one location I have visited other work sites and the experience has been the same. Lower and upper management is very supportive of their employees.
cons: Not a company fault in reality, but as contracts get awarded over time you find yourself with less appealing working/contract conditions.

review_title: Started out good but has gone steadily downhill
pros: Good benefits, pension, 9-80 work schedule, flexible hours, option to work at home when needed, at least they've finally realized what a joke the "employer of choice" tagline was
cons: Political, IDS-IT used to be a good place to work but now it's become a sweatshop, layoffs a regular event, they say they care about the employees but don't believe it

review_title: Good Company and Great People
job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: I really like working for Raytheon in Tucson. I started as a Hughes employee in 1997, but no one told me about the Hughes retirement plan. There is lots of work. The people are family. The cost of living in Tucson is low. The company, under Bill Swanson, is progressive.
cons: Tucson. Cow town. Lots of red tape. Slow to accomplish what needs to be done due to being a defense firm.

review_title: Unethical and Low Expectations
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: The individual contributors are mostly great to work with like any standard company.  The benefits are average.
cons:
Salary - They will totally low ball you and say they have no cost of living built into there salary ranges.  This isn't true. Every company has some sort of compensation for different regions.

Work - The expectations are low.  This is not good IMHO due to the types of contracts being worked on - people's lives are at stake!  The process approaches are stuck in the 80's.

Management - Needs a overhaul!  My manager says very inappropriate things and attempts to divide the teams.

review_title: Good overall company
pros:
Good benefits.
Various projects to work on throughout company.
cons:
For software engineers, it's relatively easy to get out-dated on latest technologies.  In order for you to stay competitive with the "outside world", you need to spend your own time keeping up with the latest technologies or work on IR&D which utilizes them.

There are also way too many "power point engineers".

review_title: Great Engineers, Terrible Leadership
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros: Awesome, friendly people. Management is either great, listening, trusting their employees... OR ...
cons: ... they (mgmt) are close minded, self-promoting, anti-agile, team ruining 'employees'. Really, the management here is either fantastic or horrible, and when it is bad, usually there is no escape. The worst get promoted, and kick others to the curb  that have any ounce of say in the end product.

review_title: Corporate lives in vacuum to maintain plausible deniability.
job_title: Senior Principal Systems Engineer in Woburn, MA
pros: Good money and some high tech work when you can find it.
cons: Raytheon Management is so interested about company awards, CMMI, etc. but completely uninterested in making the company actually better.  There is a lot of back-stabbers and kiss-asses which really does get one promoted.

review_title: Technical Company that is one of the world's best
pros: Raytheon prides itself on technical and engineering excellence.  It doesn't build the defense platforms that most would recognize, instead Raytheon build the insides of most advanced systems in the world.  It is a company that challenges its employees for excellence.  Very rewarding.
cons: HR system is archaic and there seems to be a large generational gap between the senior management and the average employee.

review_title: Excellent
pros:
Great opportunities to learn many new skills
Continuous on-site training opportunities available
Cross-training options when seeking career advancement
Friendly work environment
Competitive benefit package
cons: Some customers require high volume production in a short period of time, this leads to teams having to work long hours, including weekends to complete assignments

review_title: Solid financials; good place to start or rejuvenate a career
pros:
Solid balance sheet and other financials
Processes yield predictable quarterly earnings
Smart long range business strategy
Strong employee diversity and inclusion programs
Access to lots of training and self development opportunities
cons:
Difficult and time consuming for newbies to learn the culture and political landscape
Getting a promotion or moving within the company is difficult for mid and late career employees

review_title: Outstanding Company for qualified & dedicated professionals
job_title: Technical Director, Systems Integration in Tewksbury, MA
pros:
Appreciates hard work
Outstanding benefits
Diverse opportunities

review_title: There are better places to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Most people, who are not managers, are very nice.
cons: Very political.  There is a chasm between the Management and the Workers.  If you tell a manager that there is a problem with a product you may very likely be targeted for retaliation including bad reviews, less pay increases and lay off.  Example, try to find out what happened to any engineers who spoke out about problems on the Patriot Missile System in the 1990s.

review_title: Stable company where you can move around.
pros: Stable, great PTO benefits, 9/80 schedule
cons: Low annual raises, promotions and better raises are reserved for the top 5% and are more subjective than objective

review_title: Work on important and intriguing projects
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tewksbury, MA
pros:
Very interesting problems in defense and science that are changing the world, protecting the nation, and advancing technologies that leverage scienctific and mathematical research.

Good benefits.

Laid back atmosphere.
cons:
Higher concentration of fuddy duddy engineers and managers than at my current employer.

Extremely slow to adopt new technologies. You'll use ClearCase instead of Git. There's little Python in sight; if you're lucky large scripts are in Perl instead of csh shell script.

review_title: Decent

cons: Huge discrepancies in pay range.  Dis-organized matrix environment in certain depts.  Lots of politics and favoritism.  Many mid and low level managers don't have much technical backgrounds (more on the administrative side) which makes it hard for them providing meaningful support or guidance to the engineers doing the work.

review_title: One of the largest defensive contractors.
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Fullerton, CA
pros: Working at Raytheon exposes you to the defense industry and multiple aspects of the U.S. military. You definitely feel like you are contributing to the safety of the nation.
cons: All programs that employees work for are contract based. If the program doesn't win a contract, employees are left to find work in other areas.

review_title: No pay-raise for most employees in 2015
pros:
Every other friday off is a nice perk.
Work 40hours/week. Paid for OT even as an engineer.
Good benefits.
Laid-back environment.

review_title: Don't work here, I am looking to leave! Tired of lying to my employees.
job_title: Value Stream Leader in Forest, MS
pros:
Certainly, the benefits are good. 
Pay is okay too. 
They gave me a decent relocation package, which I took advantage off.
cons:
Management is plagued with incompetence, they are jerks to employees, and don't care about the well being of the employees.  Work life balance? Forget it! They just state that in the interview to get you in the door! They frown upon you going to the Doctor, taking care of family members, taking time off. A big disappointment for me was that I was promised the 9/80 work schedule, that was a huge lie, they frown upon the 9/80 work schedule. In fact, after I got hired I was told I couldn't take every other Friday off. In addition, I had to see some managers impose on employees that they do not go on 9/80 so that they can "Support the program" or "Meet a deadline". It's a lie, they just go on their little power trips.

Long hour days, weekends, unrealistic goals, and expectations. Here is the untold truth by Sr. Management. High stress levels, and a whole bunch of idiots. Way too many layers of management very few folks actually doing the job. Then all the managers complain about why isn't the job done? If you have more managers than actual employees, there is something really wrong.

They can't hire people locally as the locals know it is the worst place to work at, and the attrition rate is through the roof, people come and go every year as soon as their 1 year relocation agreement is up they are out the door. Therefore, Sr. Management have to hire people from out of town or state. The out of state folks think they are getting a great deal at Raytheon, when they are absolutely getting screwed. However, since out of town folks don't know and haven't heard the local horror stories of working at Raytheon in Forest, MS they come in only to figure out that they just made a big mistake. Be aware of getting hired full time as they can lay you off at any time, so basically you are just a contractor. If the contracts are good with money then things are okay, as soon as the money and contracts start running out then prepare for hell. The environment of FEAR is present and that's the "Motivation" to work harder. Basically, FEAR of layoff so you have to be there weekends, you have to work overtime, you have to work third shift, you have to forget about vacation, you basically sign your life away. I have gotten threats of getting fired, I have had to lie to employees to make them come during weekends and work overtime to meet some unrealistic schedule and dates. This was certainly the worst year and change of my life. Stress levels through the roof. I dreaded every day coming in to work, Sundays were just the start. Don't work here.

HR is a joke, they will lie to you to get you on the door, don't listen, don't come in, find yourself another job at a different location. You must be really crazy or desperate to move to Forest. Either be a local and work here or else my word of advise is do not work here it is a living hell.
